dialogues.speaker: JACK BAKER
dialogues.text: is standing before a dirty window, looking out at a dirty city street.  He is wearing a tuxedo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the GIRL from this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Jack looks at the Girl, sleepy and warm under the bedcovers, then at the rest of the apartment.   Not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha doin' over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Job. The Girl glances at the bedside clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will I see you again? Jack looks out at the dirty street again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The Girl doesn't appear terribly unnerved by this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the tux)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't wearing that, were you? Earlier. Jack shakes his head, taps a brown paper bag on the sill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brought it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, thank God.  You look like a creep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I'd hate to think I'd pick up someone who wore that shit. Jack smiles, grabs the paper bag, and moves to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. (as he stops)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got great hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack ain't exactly Cary Grant, but any guy wearing a tux on these streets doesn't exactly mesh with the milieu.  Pausing for a flask of whiskey at an all-night liquor store, he breaks the seal before he hits the sidewalk and moves on, drinking as he goes.  Finally, he comes to a nice downtown hotel.   Slipping the bottle in his coat, he squints up at the glittering building as if sizing up an opponent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jackie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How goes it, Tommy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, you know. Howsa pooch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Losing his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit. It's the goddamn water. Kill an ox. I buy bottled for my Danny. You can't trust the taps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (standing back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, you look like fucking royalty, Tommy. Tommy brushes at his new velvet coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  The big boys sent it down yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another five years, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like clockwork.  You got a good memory, Jackie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't always a blessing.  My brother here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got blood in his eye. Jack glances at his watch, waves to Tommy, and moves into the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Jack's older brother, FRANK, is pacing outside the lounge when he sees Jack approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.  Terrific.  Glad you could make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How we doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How we ... ? What, are you kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking out a cigarette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cannot continue to walk in at the last moment, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to show up late a few nights?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank.  I'm here.  I always get here.  Don't sweat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, will you look at your hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack turns to the wall, which is paneled in tiny tinted mirrors shot through with veins of gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like you just crawled out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's gonna be looking at my hair.  Come on, we're on. Frank just stands there, bottled up with exasperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Careful, Frank.  When you get angry your tie starts to spin. Jack steps into the lounge and Frank, shaking his head, follows.  As they move away, a cardboard stand-up is revealed.  On it are two 8 X 10 glossies of Frank and Jack, and below printed in bold letters, this: "Tonight!  The Doubly Delightful Tones of the Fabulous Baker Boys!"

dialogues.speaker: BAKER BROTHERS
dialogues.text: as they make their way through the dimly-lit lounge and settle behind matching pianos, it becomes apparent that what the "Fabulous Baker Boys" are, in fact, is a poor man's version of Ferrante and Teicher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they begin to plink out their "theme song" tables of middle-aged couples sipping enormous banana daiquiries begin to tap their feet and bob their heads. After a few bars, the boys finish with a flourish and the couples applaud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Mr.  Smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Thank you.  Good evening and welcome to the Starfire lounge.  My name is Frank Baker and eighty-eight keys across from me is my little brother, Jack. Applause.  Little brother Jack smiles, winks, and takes a draw on his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; could do this in his sleep)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, my brother and I have been playing together, gosh, I don't know.  How long has it been, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-eight years, Frank. Applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lot of water under the bridge, eh, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotta water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, back then, things were a little different.  I was eight, Jack was seven, just about the only song we knew was 'My Bonnie Lies Over the Ocean', and the only one who would listen to us was the family cat, Cecil. (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must have shaved three lives off that cat, eh, Jack? Laughter. Jack smiles like he's got a mouth full of razor blades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But seriously.  It's been fifteen years since Jack and I first stepped on the stage as professionals. Three states, sixty-eight cities, and more-grayhairs-then-we'd-like-to-admit later... well, believe me, we've seen our share of this crazy country of ours.  But even though we've played some of the finest venues in the world ... At this point, Jack begins to mimic his brother's words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... There's one place that's always been, for us, a very special place, and that place is... this place, the Starfire lounge. Jack lays in a few soft bass chords.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  Well, I guess you could just say it's the ... (pregnant moment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... people. At which point Frank's hands descend onto the keyboard and give birth to the melody of -- what else?  "People.'

dialogues.speaker: JACK AND FRANK
dialogues.text: They exit the stage to applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Remember, room service is available till one A.M. for you late-nighters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Frank pass through the steamy hotel kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make trouble, all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's gonna make trouble? (spotting someone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, amigo!

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: in an apron, cutting meat off a huge soup bone, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack! (lower)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the feeling's mutual)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, hi, Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: the soup bone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Eddie.  I wrap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gracias.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as they exit)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it, Jack.  Behave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like an angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank stands across the desk from a YOUNG MAN who, despite his youth, has an irritatingly paternal attitude toward the two men in his office.  Jack stays in the doorway, smoking a cigarette, as if to venture any further is to risk contracting some hideous disease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (preparing a cash envelope)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific, boys.  Really.  Terrific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  You're just what we needed on a night like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh ... thanks. Frank glances at Jack and realizes he should have left him in the kitchen with Hector and the soup bone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only, Jack, do me a favor, will ya, pal?  If you wanna smoke, put on a pair of sunglasses and go play with the niggers on State Street.  These blisters from the midwest don't wanna watch some guy dripping ash all over himself while he's playing 'The Sound of Music.'

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Smoke curls out of Jack's nose.  He is utterly still, like a pit bull eyeing a steak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, boys, that ought to buy you a few more lessons.  By the way, Frankie, I'm declaring this. Lloyd slaps a slender envelope onto the desk and, business closed, busies himself with other matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh ... You don't know when you'll be wanting us back, do you, Lloyd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, well, you know, the way our schedule is, I thought maybe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you. Frank bites down and takes the envelope from the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count the fucking money, Frank. Lloyd looks up.  Jack is staring right into him. Reluctantly, Frank opens the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all here. (pulling Jack out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be talking to you, Lloyd. Lloyd doesn't answer.  He just looks at Jack, smiling with amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack comes out onto the street holding the wrapped soup bone, dogged by Frank, who's got the cardboard stand-up under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mind telling me what that was about in there? Was that planned?   Or were you just bored and decided to get creative?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't the Pine Tree Inn on Route 81, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck him.  Great.  Terrific.  Fuck him. The fabulous Bakers walk in silence until they come to Frank's car. Frank opens the trunk and starts to put the stand-up away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we on tomorrow night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe Thursday.  I hear the harpist at the Sheraton's got appendicitis. Jack nods and starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Jack stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen ... why don't you come out to the house this weekend.  Say hello to the kids.   They've grown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate your kids, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're their uncle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only by relation.  Besides, they hate me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't.  They're always asking about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tried to electrocute me, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was no fucking accident, Frank. The little one ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She threw a goddamn radio into the bathtub.   How do you explain that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't know what she was doing. You're too sensitive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got weird kids, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I just thought if you came out you might see what you're missing. Jack just stares at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just think about it, all right? Consider it a standing offer. Frank closes the trunk and moves to the driver's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing;like a litany)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a ride, Jack?  No, Frank, I'll walk.  Okay, Jack, good night. Good night, Frank. Frank turns the ENGINE OVER and pulls away from the curb. Jack watches the taillights burn into the distance, then takes the whiskey bottle from his coat and heads for home.

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT BUILDING
dialogues.text: Jack crosses the street and waves up to his apartment building, where a black labrador is studying him from a second story window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's apartment is small, old, and comfortably cluttered.  The most striking item is a vintage phone booth placed against the wall.  As Jack lets himself in, EDDIE, the dog from the window, walks over.  He is not an overly enthusiastic dog, but you can see from his face that he has a great deal of affection for Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, pal.  Thought you were gonna clean the apartment. Eddie nuzzles the soup bone.  Jack unwraps the paper and hands it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, will ya?  You're becoming a regular Johhny Appleseed the way you're dropping teeth around here. Jack hangs his tie on the phone booth and walks over to an old phonograph stacked six deep with discs.   He lifts the records back up the post and clicks ON the MACHINE.  As Bill Evans' smoky "PEACE PIECE" fills the tiny apartment, Jack breaks the collar of his shirt and walks over to the old piano near the window.  Settling back with the bottle of whiskey, Jack rests his elbows gently on the keys and stares out the open window, listening to the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Frank work opposite sides of a large piano showroom, inspecting rentals of every style and color. WILLIE, the owner of the place, leans against a cheap upright, contemplating his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to the two Clays, Willie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they coming in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wednesday next. Frank looks across the room at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'ya got?,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bosen black. (taps a key)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'you say, Willie?  Tighten her up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the gig?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two nights. Willie just looks at his shoes and shakes his head. Frank frowns and glances around. Across the room, Jack pauses before another piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'ya got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yamaha white.  Nice. Frank moves to another grand and alternates taps with his brother to see if the two pianos are in harmony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try the black Knable. Frank moves to another piano and repeats the process, watching Jack for a verdict. After a moment, Jack nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tag 'em, Willie.  The Regency downtown, Thursday-Friday.  Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brothers sit at a window of a corner diner, Jack nursing an ice coffee, Frank playing with a plate of scrambled eggs.   The glass next to them is cluttered with photographs of neighborhood luminaries, including two of Jack and Frank in their tuxedoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I think it's been five years since I saw you eat anything. That's the God's truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me, you're not missing anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.  You sleeping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only on odd days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing anyone in particular?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the interest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm your brother.  Because I care about you. Because sometimes it seems like the most significant relationship in your life is with that goddamn dog of yours. Jack studies his brother's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not seeing anyone.  In particular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about that waitress at the Ambassador?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-uh.  How about you?  You seeing anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny. (points at his wedding band)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strike a bell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only a ring.  Not a collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more than that. Jack smiles and sips his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, we gotta go see Ma tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta go, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you gotta go 'cause if you don't get up there every couple weeks you feel guilty.   I won't feel guilty, so I don't gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time you gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your older brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're thirteen months older than me, Frank. That might've meant something in the Apache clubhouse, but it don't cut too deep anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, Jack, it's her birthday. Jack glances up.  Frank nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you say? Think the city can spare you for an afternoon? Jack squints out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  And don't worry about a present. I got her something from both of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, cradling a pink bakery box in one hand, gets out of Frank's car and surveys the street on which he grew up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make sure you lock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless you count the elderly gentleman picking roses three houses down, there would not appear to be a wealth of potential car thieves in the immediate vicinity. But it's not Jack's car, so he doesn't press the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Place looks good, huh?  I got a neighbor boy to mow the lawn, pick up. Five bucks.   Times've changed, huh? (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See the tree? Remember the job Cecil did on it the day Dad planted it? You can still see the scars on the trunk.  Really. I was looking at it just the other day. Jesus, I thought he was gonna kill that cat. Frank smiles, recalling Cecil's near-demise, then raps on the front door. Jack studies the tree a moment, then gestures to the tiny ribboned box in Frank's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what'd we get her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: At that moment, the door swings open and ELLIE BAKER is there, a vibrant woman in her sixties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if it isn't the fabulous Baker Boys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the birthday girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little stiffer, but just as sturdy. Mrs. Baker hugs Frank, then, a bit awkwardly, embraces Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John.  It's good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable; balancing cake box)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you, Ma. Jack looks over his mother's shoulder at Frank and mimics "John" with a knowing nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Ma, you know, no one calls him that anymore. Jack. He goes by Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought maybe held gotten over that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty years, Ma ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes.  It's just that John is so much nicer. Jack sounds so ... crude. When I was a little girl, we had a pig on the farm named Jack. I guess I just can't help making the association. Jack's eyes slide over to Frank as if to suggest he holds his brother personally responsible for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh ... yeah, well, you know, Ma, John Kennedy went by Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catholics.  What do you expect?   Oh, well, what's in a name, right? Let's go inside and have a look at that cake. As Mrs. Baker exits, Frank leans over to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep her busy, will ya? I have to set a few things up. Frank disappears, leaving Jack alone on the porch with the bakery box.  Jack shakes his head, wondering how he's going to make it through the afternoon then enters the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front room is cluttered with his childhood.   Most noticeable are the pianos: two tiny uprights, perfectly matched, their simulated ivory keys yellowed with age.  Above them, pressed between glass and framed, are the music ribbons, faded by twenty years of sunlight. Finally, there is the sheet music, dusty and dog-eared, piled everywhere in drunken stacks. This and all else in the room Jack confronts slowly, warily, but with a noticeable dispassion, until his eyes fall upon a photograph. In it, he and Frank are standing alonside a tall man in baggy slacks, safe within the arc of his long arms. Frank is staring straight into the camera, neat, clean, perfectly posed, but Jack, a year younger, his shirt too big, is caught in profile, looking up at the tall man with an almost worshipful gaze

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now, where's everyone run off to? Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. All at once, Jack and his mother realize they are alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, shall we cut that cake? Jack nods and follows her into the kitchen. He places the box on the table and stands off to the side while Mrs. Baker sets about preparing things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.  You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, fine. Silence. Jack watches his mother poise the knife over the cake. Her fingers are trembling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big piece or little?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not much for sweets. Mrs. Baker nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that dog of yours?  What was his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Right.  Eddie.  How is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's losing his teeth. Mrs. Baker stops and looks up into Jack's eyes. Suddenly, a NOISE is heard in the other room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like your brothers back with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank comes stumbling up the basement stairs with an old movie projector and a roll-up screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's all this? Frank sets the projector down and hands his mother the tiny ribboned box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. Jack watches from the kitchen doorway as Mrs. Baker pulls the ribbon off the box.   Inside is a tiny spool of film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, what's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blank screen, curtains drawn, the room dark.   Frank clicks on the projector and picks up his cake.   Mrs. Baker close on his elbow, sets her plate on her knees and watches the screen.   Jack sits off to the side.   A title card appears: "For Mrs. Ellie Baker, who made it all possible." Mrs. Baker gives Frank a puzzled look.   He just smiles. Suddenly, images spring to the screen, obviously footage several years old, showing Jack and Frank as children, sitting at the tiny pianos, wearing matching suits, smiling matching smiles as they play for the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recognize these two characters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought these were lost.   Where did you find ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the attic.  Behind some of Dad's stuff. (pointing with his fork)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Jack can hardly reach the pedals. As Frank's laughter fills the dark room, Jack stares with cold fascination at the screen.   Suddenly, a jagged cut springs the boys a year later, in the same positions, smiling the same smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a boy down at the camera shop cut them all together.  Boy, old man Henderson didn't fool around when he gave a haircut, did he, Jack? Jack says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, look at you two.  So skinny. And those tiny suits ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.  Watch.  Here comes Dad. Jack's eyes narrow as the film jumps another year and a man enters the frame, obviously by accident.   He is so tall his face cannot be seen.   As he dances quickly out of sight, he ruffles Jack's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man. As the film jumps again, Jack glances at the photograph to his right. The images on the screen flicker softly off the glass of the picture frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, look how you're growing. My little boys ... Jack's eyes drift from the photograph to his mother and brother, sitting close together in the love seat, laughing.  After a moment, their voices fade and Jack looks back to the children on the screen, like two tiny men, mirror images of one another. At first the changes are subtle.   Little Jack's tie is askew, his shirt missing a button. But as the years flick by, the brothers resemble one another less and less, until finally, the little boy that was Jack is completely gone and in his place is a slouching, tousle-haired adolescent in rumpled coat and open collar, a cigarette hanging disdainfully from his lip.   A woman's hand darts into the frame and plucks the offending cigarette away in a flash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Jack are parked in front of Jack's building. Whispers of steam snake from the mancovers in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made her nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hands.  Like that. Jack holds out a trembling hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah.  Medication. Jack looks over at Frank.  He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couple years, now. (taps his heart)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeps the beat steady.  Nothing serious. Jack considers this a moment, then gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was glad to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack lets himself into his apartment and stops. Across the room, curled up on the couch, is a little girl Jack takes the girl gently in his arms and carries her to the bedroom.  As he folds a blanket under her chin, he pauses. The girl's face is calm, peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning.  Early.   The sun is peeking sleepily between the buildings and beginning to drip out onto the street.  Suddenly, RINGING OUT over the rooftops, is "JINGLE BELLS" -- not the entire song, just the first two bars, over and over.

dialogues.speaker: IHT. JACK'S APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Jack, on the couch, his arm draped over a slumbering Eddie, opens his eyes.  Across the room, seated at the piano, is NINA, the little girl. She stops playing and turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.  You want coffee?  I made coffee. Jack looks into the sleepy face of Eddie and sits up. He nods to the coffee.  Nina goes to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did the dishes last night. You're missing a cup. Jack rubs his head, then gets up and walks to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you break a cup, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie did. Nina looks at Eddie, sleeping on the couch, then brings Jack his coffee with both hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I practiced the piano last night.  Two hours. I think I'm ready for 'Jingle all the way.' Jack nods.  Suddenly, the sound of HEAVY FOOTSTEPS is hea Jack and Nina glance up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess they're up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds big.  What's he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Process server. Ma said it's like a lawyer only the hours are more regular.  All I know's he came to take the TV one afternoon and ended up staying for dinner.  And breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to the donut king?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Married. Upstairs, a DOOR SLAMS and HEAVY FEET ECHO in the stairwell. Nina peers out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No breakfast.  Maybe they had a fight. TWO DEEP THUMPS sound on the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, gotta go.  Teach me later? Jack nods. Nina kisses him on the cheek and exits. Jack walks over to the couch and gives Eddie a nudge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Though the plastic palms and grass-skirted waitresses of the Luau Lounge make the Fabulous Baker Boys' presence seem a bit incongruous, Jack and Frank hold nothing back, giving "McCarthur Park" the full treatment.   Unfortunately, the audience in the Luau Lounge wouldn't fill a Hawaiian haystack and their applause is less than volcanic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, thank you.  That concludes our show for this evening.  Jack and I only hope you enjoyed yourselves as much as we did. As the guests wander out, clutching their roomkeys, a freckle-faced BELLHOP comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Baker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tired)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Simpson asked to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, tell him I'll be right there. As Jimmy exits, Frank stands and points at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow we close with the 'Aquarius Suite.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank pauses before a door marked "HOTEL MANAGER." It's half-open.  Inside, CHARLIE SIMPSON, a heavy man in a shiny suit, is throwing darts in the general direction of a dartboard.  He's not very good.  Frank knocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to see me, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little slow tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waving it off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mondays. Charlie takes an envelope from his desk and hands it to Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now?  Why not tomorrow?  After the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't need you, Frankie. For a moment, Frank just stands there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got the grands for two nights, Charlie.  You can't just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all there.  Both nights. Frank looks at the envelope in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you saying, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Frankie.  You and Jack been playing here, a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, twelve years.  Couple times a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So maybe it's time we took a vacation from each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vacation?  Christ, Charlie, it's a Monday night. You said so yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't half full out there tonight, Frankie. I got six waiters standing in back listening to baseball.  I gotta move the liquor.   To move the liquor, I gotta fill the tables.   It's a matter of economics.  Me, I love you. I love both you guys, you know that.   You're class.  But people today.   They don't know class if it walks up and grabs 'em by the balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack rises as Frank passes through the lobby with the cardboard stand-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  Everything's great. Terrific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the stand-up under his arm, Frank enters and closes the door quietly.   A light is glowing in the kitchen.   The rest of the house is dark, quiet.  In the kitchen, he checks the message pad by the phone.  Nothing.   On the table, a plate of cold chicken is waiting for him. Next to it is a stack of bills with a note attached: "Frank. Please." Frank sighs and leans the stand-up against the wall.   The photo of Jack is peeling off the cardboard.   Finding a stack of glossies in a drawer, Frank removes the old Jack from the stand-up and replaces it with a new one.   As he presses the photograph in place, his eyes drift to the one of himself.   It was taken a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack places a record on the turntable and sits at the piano by the window.  As the needle hits the spinning disc, a sharp, snappy BASS LINE REVERBERATES throughout the apartment.  Jack takes a drink, then joins in with the record, playing along.  His concentration is intense, so much so that, a moment later, when the PHONE RINGS, he seems not to hear it.  Finally, he picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Listen ... come out to the house tomorrow, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had enough family for one month, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not family.  It's business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So talk to me tomorrow.  After the gig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't get a gig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something came up.  Don't worry, Charlie stayed true.  Both nights. I'll give you your share tomorrow. At the house. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you'll come out, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. Jack listens to the PHONE HISSING in the dark, then the CONNECTION goes DEAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi lets Jack off on a street of shabby tract houses. In his rumpled city suit, Jack looks like a cheap gangster amid the weedy lawns and overgrown junipers.   He walks up to the door of a small white house and presses the doorbell. When there is no response, he goes around to the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The backyard is small, with a short chainlink fence surrounding it.  Two kids, a girl and a boy, are splashing around in a build-it-yourself above-ground pool.   When they see Jack, they stop splashing. Only their heads are visible above the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, kids.  Dad home? The two heads say nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What d'ya say?  Wanna run and get him for me? Still nothing.  Jack frowns, takes out a cigarette, and pats his pocket for a match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. The kids' eyes widen at his profanity.   Jack, the unlit cigarette dangling from his lip, ponders things for a moment, then flicks the'cigarette away and steps over the fence. At which point, the tinier of the two heads in the pool begins to scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, kid.  Take it easy. No use.  The kid's a world-class screamer.   Frank, wearing baggy shorts and looking alarmed, comes racing out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cindy!  What is it? Cindy points.  At Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your doorbell doesn't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, it's only Uncle Jack.  You remember Uncle Jack. DONNA, Frank's wife, appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?  Jack? Jack waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifting Cindy out of the pool)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's the matter. Is it, sweetheart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take her inside.  You too, little Frank.  Out of the pool. Donna shepherds the kids toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feet! The kids wipe their dripping feet on the outside mat and disappear into the house.  Frank turns to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's probably the excitement of seeing you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna comes out of the house with a tray of lemonade. The men are sitting by the pool in a pair of webbed aluminum chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bring trunks, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trunks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swimming trunks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. No. Strictly dryland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad.  You could use some sun. Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe next time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have some lotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suit yourself. Donna returns to the house. Frank takes a sip of his lemonade and scans his surroundings complacently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trees.  The flowers.  Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (expansively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ... we're gonna paint in the spring. After the rains.  Look good as new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ask me out here to sell me your house, Frank? Frank shakes the ice in his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie paid you off last night, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you.  Something came up. Some political dinner or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.  Fifteen years, Frank. No one paid us off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey pal, I got a mortgage, all right?   I got two kids. I got a wife. Besides, he made the deal.   There's no shame in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That how you see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's how I see it. Jack shakes his head in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't go shaking your head, little brother. I'm not the one who walks in every night smelling like he's got a day job in a piss factory. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It killed him, you know. Jack glances up.  Dangerous territory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gust of wind killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and what put him up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you weren't there.  Right? Jack's look ends this.  Frank sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, can we forget last night? We gotta talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been thinking maybe we should make some changes. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been thinking maybe we should take on a singer. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, why not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just an idea.  I want your opinion. I mean, we go halfway on everything, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more like 40-60, wouldn't you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We agreed that if I took care of the business; I'd be entitled to the extra. Isn't that what we agreed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what we agreed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're unhappy with the arrangement --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd like to assume more of the financial responsibilities, I'd be glad --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank.  Fuck it.  Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've tried to do well by you, Jack. By both of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm grateful, Frank.  How much? For the singer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought maybe twenty percent. Look, with the additional bookings we'll come out ahead.  The big hotels, they want a pretty girl with a big voice. We have to stay competitive, Jack. Jack laughs coldly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, Frank.  All these years you been telling me we're different.  We got novelty, Jack. No one can touch us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two pianos isn't enough anymore, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It never was.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: in pink sweater and a short black skirt stands in the center of a tiny room in the back of Willie's piano showroom, holding some sheet music.  Sammy Davis Jr.'s face is on the sheet music.  Frank is sitting against the opposite wall, a notepad in his hand.   Jack is at the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Miss...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moran.  Monica Moran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Miss Moran

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, that's my stage name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moran.  Monica.  The whole thing.   It's my stage name.  My real name's Blanche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blanche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No romance, right?  That's why I came up with Monica. It's what I prefer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's fine --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if you call my house and my mother answers, ask for Blanche.  If you ask for Monica, she'll think you have the wrong number and hang up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if she asks what it's about, don't tell her. She's opposed to my career.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.  Well, Miss Moran, what is it you'd like to do for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy Man.' (worried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's one of Jack's favorites. Monica turns and, seeing Jack at the piano, gives a little start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oops.  I almost forgot you were there.  Here's the music. Monica begins to hand Jack the sheet music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  Isn't that a coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Small world. Monica smiles.  She likes Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, shall we? Probably not, but Jack begins to play anyway, laconically picking out the cheery tune while Monica swings her arms and taps her foot. Despite all this, Monica still manages to come in between beats and Jack has to scramble over a chord to catch her, sort of like a fireman with a net.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who can take a sunrise Sprinkle it with dew Toss it in the air and Make a groovy lemon pie The Candy Man can The Candy Man can..., There would appear to be ample evidence as to why the mother of Monica nee Blanche opposes her daughter's career.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss Moran, that's enough. Monicals eyes are closed now and she is fully caught up. Frank looks over at Jack.   Jack shrugs and continues to play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Moran ... Miss Moran ... Blanche! Monica's eyes pop open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry.  I get so caught up in it sometimes.  It's scary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... thanks. (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drive carefully. As Monica exits, Jack and Frank glance at one another and thus begins a seemingly endless parade of aspiring singers who can't sing.  As Frank sinks lower in his chair and Jack's ashtray spills over with wounded cigarettes, singer after singer, in all shapes, sizes, and colors, come forth to offer their own unique interpretations of "Feelings," "I Gotta Be Me," "This Is My Song," and perhaps most appropriately, "What Kind of Fool Am I." Finally, when it is all over, Jack and Frank are left alone in the tiny room, looking dazed, exhausted, and mildly homicidal.

dialogues.speaker: TALL YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: As the sequence ends, a TALL YOUNG WOMAN in high heels walks into Willie's.  She glances around, then spots Willie across the room, eating a corn beef on rye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.  You one of the fabulous Baker Boys?

dialogues.speaker: JACK AND FRANK
dialogues.text: are putting on their coats, preparing to leave. Frank is staring at his notepad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-seven.  Thirty-seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-seven girls. And not one who can carry a tune. That must be statistically impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a somewhat extraordinary day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't understand.  You would think someone ... anyone ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn! The Woman in high heels stumbles into the doorway, holding a shoe in her hand.  It's broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brand new Thursday.  You believe it? After today, Jack and Frank are prepared to believe anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This where the auditions are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where the auditions were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about me? Frank looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an hour and a half late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My watch is broken, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Punctuality.  First rule of show business. The Woman looks around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is show business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in no mood)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, miss.  We're tired, you have gum on your lip, and we're going home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touching her lip)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like that, huh?  You're not even gonna give me a chance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take it personally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How should I take it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impersonally. Frank begins to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it.  I come all the way down down here, break a heel, and you're not gonna give me a chance because I have gum on my lip and I'm a few minutes late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an hour and a half late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if I'm so 'late how come you're still here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ran long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So run a little longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You find a girl? Jack and Frank glance at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. I'm here, you're here, the piano's here.  What d'ya say? Before Frank can answer, Jack walks over to the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific.  Thirty-eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that mean?  Thirty-eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Frank)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I'm feeling a lot of hostility from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appealing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get it over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie.  Susie Diamond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catchy.  You have any previous entertainment experience, Miss Diamond?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... for the last four years I've been on call to Triple A Escort service. Jack and Frank exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's legit.  Strictly dinner and dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  I think that's all we need to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sing now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the premise. Susie gives Frank a dark look, then turns to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I Get Along Without You.' Slowly, okay? Jack nods and begins to play.   Frank slouches down in his chair, preparing to be tortured again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get along without you very well Of course I do Except when soft rains fall And drip from leaves, then I recall The thrill of being Sheltered in your arms Of course I do But I get along without you very well.' Susie stops.  Frank just sits there.   Jack just sits there.  She can sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blinking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh ... we'll let you know. Jack looks over at Frank like he's insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't leave a girl hanging. Second rule of show business. Frank's not amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, okay.  'Bye, Bakers. Susie walks out barefoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just thought we should talk about it.  Between ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's there to talk about?  She can sing.   That puts her at the head of the class. That makes her the only one in the class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know ... She had gum on her lip, for Christ sake.   I don't think she's right for the act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting cold feet about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just thinking what Ma would think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma? Ma?  Was Ma there the last time we played the Ambassador?  Oh, that's right, she was on bass. How could I forget. Frank frowns and looks down at his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many other silent partners are there, Frank? Donna?  Little Cindy?   Hell, let's give Eddie a vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay.  I'll call the girl. Frank gets up wearily, then glances down at the notepad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get her number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Frank dash out of Willie's and glance up and down the street.  Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can always look her up in the book. JACK. Right.  Susie Diamond.  She's probably listed right next to Monica Moran. Jack shakes his head in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this mean I get the job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Frank whirl around. There, standing in the doorway, is Susie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intuition.

dialogues.speaker: CITY SKYLINE
dialogues.text: Gleaming beautifully at the start of a new day.   Once again, "JINGLE BELLS" is heard, only this time carried a little further: "Jingle bells, jingle bells, jingle all the way..."

dialogues.speaker: JACK, FRANK AND SUSIE
dialogues.text: Ensconsed in the back room of Willie's, preparing for their first rehearsal ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready? Jack nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready? Susie nods.  Frank poises his hands over the piano, hesitates, then looks at Jack again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready? Jack squints at Frank, then nods.   Frank turns to Susie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we, an orchestra all of a sudden? Frank g1ares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Frank poises his hands over the piano again and begins to play the opening passage of "Just the Way You Are." A moment later, Jack joins in, and a moment after that, Susie.  Unfortunately, Jack and Frank, accustomed to playing alone, are a tad overwhelming and the result sounds like a fifth grade recital. After a few bars, Susie holds up her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fellas, fellas ... Jack and Frank stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The problem is I can't hear myself sing with all this... (searching)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... music.  You know what I'm saying? Jack and Frank look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, back there it may be hard to notice, but up here I'm having a little trouble getting a word in. Jack and Frank just stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, you're supposed to be backing me up, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (icily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We are not supposed to be backing you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I mean is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're a team.  We work together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So work with me, not against me. Okay? Frank stares at Susie for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose we can bring it down a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drop the eighths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay? Susie looks at the two brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIE'S SHOWROOM
dialogues.text: Frank is on Willie's telephone.   In the front of the store, just out of earshot, Jack sits at a beat-up grand, while Susie moves aimlessly from one piano to another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, Ray.  She's got a voice like an angel ... What? Frank glances furtively across the room to where Susie, making a very sexy silhouette against the front window, is running her hand over a pearl-white piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I wouldn't say she's got a body like an angel. As Frank continues to talk in the background, Susie looks over at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, he's not sore, is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll come around. Susie nods, goes back to stroking the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never sang before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for money. With my mother. Jack nods slowly, but Susie sees he doesn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She used to waitress downtown, nights, when I was a kid.  On the way home, we'd sing. You know how people whistle when they're nervous? My mother sang.  She always said you're never alone with a song 'cause thousands of people know the same song and even though you can't hear 'em, they're singing with you.  I don't know.   If they were, they were all singing safe inside their apartments. (shrugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it worked.  We always got home.  Ever since, I always wanted to sing.   I never took lessons or anything, though. I guess you guys took a lot of lessons. Jack looks down at the piano in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  We took a lot of lessons.

dialogues.speaker: JACK AND NINA
dialogues.text: Jack's tuxedo is hanging in the shower as he gets ready for the night's gig.  Nina, standing next to him at the sink, watches as he works up a lather on a bar of shaving soap, then paints his face with the suds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shave like an old movie, Jack. As Jack picks up a razor, Nina takes the brush and begins to soap her face in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the old days, every man had a shaving mug that he kept at the barber shop.  Then, whenever he wanted a shave, held go down to the barber shop and there would be his mug, waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you used to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My days are not the old days, genius.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The recent past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (nodding to the ceiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bigfoot gets his out of a can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw his stuff in the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it's getting serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he'll ask your ma to marry him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope not.  He's already busted the springs in two chairs.  Hey, what's this? Nina holds up the handle of the shaving brush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ivory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Older than me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. Jack gives Nina a look, then begins to splash his face. Nina picks up the razor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what do you want to do?  Grow a beard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's get your first prom under the belt, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a prom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever go to church? Nina nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like that.  Only you gotta dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jack enters the hotel, he passes by the cardboard stand-up, prominently displayed in the lobby.   It is virtually unchanged, except for a small notation at the bottom: "With Guest Vocalist." On the other side of the lobby, Frank is pacing nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told everyone seven-fifteen. Didn't I? Seven-fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll get here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like the day of the auditions, right?  Jesus.  How's my hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awe inspiring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, Your's isn't. (taking out a comb)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me run a comb though it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, stand still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not gonna hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll hit you, Frank.  I swear. Frank hesitates, like a basketball player trying to feint an opponent, then takes a flick at Jack's hair. Jack hits him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding his shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hit me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you I was gonna hit you. He looks capable of hitting him again, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right.  I'm a little tense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a fucking alarm clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wish she'd get here, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's here. Susie, wearing a flamboyant orange dress, is standing across the lobby, staring at the stand-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, look at her. You'd think if she was gonna wear her street clothes she'd have enough sense to come in the back. (walking over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Miss Diamond.  You're late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What-?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how come you guys are the only ones with your pictures on the poster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll talk about it later.  Right now, you gotta get changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Changed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your dress?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a language problem here?  Your dress. For tonight.  Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I look like I'm naked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That!  You can't wear that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's orange!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I missing something? Before Jack can reply, Frank grabs Susie's hand and pulls her toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.  We don't have much time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, Jack and Susie dash through a cavernous downtown department store, the brothers turning a few heads with their tuxedoes.  As they reach the ladies' department, Frank begins to flip through the dress racks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you ask me, this is pretty stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just look.  What do you wear? A nine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offended)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife wears a seven.  You don't look like a seven to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wear a seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay.  Here, how about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save it for your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not exactly silly with time, you know.  Jack, you find anything? Jack, somewhat out of his element, is looking at belts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, how's this? Frank holds out an inky black dress.  Susie gives it a long look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close enough.  Let's go. Frank begins to drag Susie into the dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, pal.  I don't know about you, but where I come from there's a little girl's room and a little boy's room and the little boys don't go where the little girls go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, but make it quick. (remembering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoes!  What size do you wear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the dressing room)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Jack work the shoe department, scouting the endless rows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding one up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, for crying out loud.  Your bachelorhood's showing. (seeing something)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, here we go. Frank grabs a pretty blue pump and gestures to the SALESMAN, who's waiting on a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  Do these come in black?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be with you in a minute, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a minute, pal.  Yes or no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glowering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  They come in black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  Give me a pair of nines. Pronto. The Salesman looks casually at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he want a pair, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jack and Frank return to the dress department, Frank jettisons the shoebox and tissue paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, we got your shoes. Just then, Susie steps out of the dressing room. Even Frank stops at the sight of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zip me up? The dress is open down to the small of her back. It's a nice back. Jack takes the zipper and closes the panels carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Frank puts the shoes down and Susie steps into them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're nines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they're aspiring to be sevens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can buy new ones tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.  We'll take it out of your share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a prince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the trio rushes into the hotel service entrance, RAY, the assistant manager, appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better buy yourself a watch, Frankie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a little emergency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I've got a little emergency. You know what I'm saying? (seeing Susie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this, Minnie Pearl? All eyes turn to Susie's dress, which still has the tags attached.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want seventy-five minutes, Frankie. You hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is going well, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three rush into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need scissors over here! Who's got scissors? (turning to Susie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, remember.  Jack and I go on first, I do the set-up, then introduce you. And you say ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, ladies and gentlemen.   I can't tell you how thrilled I am to be here.   It's like a dream come true. And speaking of dreams ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piece of cake. A tiny MAN in an apron walks up with a meat cleaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carlos, that's,a cleaver.  I need scissors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No scissors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.  All right.  Let's go, Jack.  Fix your tie. Jack and Frank exit.   Susie stares a little warily at Carlos and his cleaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Frank slide quickly behind their pianos.   About half the tables in the room are filled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, ladies and gentlemen.   Welcome to the Ambassador Lounge.   My name's Frank Baker and no, you're not seeing double, it's just my little brother, Jack. Some laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you're all in such a good mood tonight, because we've got a very special evening planned ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie sits on a stool while Carlos positions the dress ta on a cutting board.  As a WAITRESS from the bar passes by Susie snares a drink from her tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a sip.  To kill the butterflies, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  But no lipstick. Susie takes a quick sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.  No one's the wiser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice dress. As the Waitress exits, Carlos brings the cleaver down with a sharp chop, severing the tags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Appreciate it, Ace.

dialogues.speaker: LOUNGE
dialogues.text: The audience is laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But seriously, folks, as I sit here tonight, looking out on all your kind faces, I can't help but feel some of us have met before.  We may not know each other's names, we might not recognize one another on the street, but we know each other just the same.  And over the years we've shared something.  A little music, a little drink, a little laughter, maybe even... a few tears.   But I guess that's what friends are for, huh? Applause.  Jack puts out his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's especially nice to be among friends tonight, because, well, tonight's a very special night for my brother and I. This evening we've asked a young lady to join us, a lady Jack and I are sure will soon seem like just another old friend to you all.  She's making her debut here this evening and, as far as I'm concerned, she couldn't be doing it in a better place. Because there's one place that's always been for us a very special place, and that place is this place, the Ambassador Lounge.
