Ladies and gentlemen, please welcome a very special lady with a very special way of singing a song, Miss Susie Diamond. Applause.  Susie strides out of the kitchen, past the busing station, and up to the microphone stand, which, unfortunately, is not on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The switch.  Hit the switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Switch? (as she hits it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What fucking switch? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; very demure)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me. Jack and Frank look at one another, then, before outrage can set in, plunge into the opening number.   Susie takes the mike from the stand and smiles sweetly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't tell you how thrilled I am to be here. For the moment, the audience doesn't seem quite sure how thrilled they are to be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all smiles, darling Through and through...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BELLBOY exits the elevator and, hearing Susie's voice coming from the lounge, stops.   He looks to the CLERK behind the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought the Bakers were on tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, who's that? The Clerk looks up from the register and listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judging from the faces, Susie's as big a hit in the lounge as she is in the lobby.  Head thrown back, eyes closed, she sings with abandon, finishing on a long extended note, then swooping down in a dramatic, exhausted bow.  There is a split second of silence, then thunderous applause.  Magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new trio, fresh off their first gig, come out of the service entrance into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking.  She says fucking in front of an entire room of people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I was sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, they were all on their third Mai Tais by the time I got out there anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (directly to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Christ sake, I said it, I didn't do it. (pulling out some bills)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, I don't think they were too offended, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing the bills)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are not a saloon act.  We do not take tips from dirty old men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was gonna split it with you guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do not take tips.  I'll apply this to the cost of the dress. Frank puts the money in his pocket.  Susie stares at him, steaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I want my name on the poster. And my picture! (taking off her shoes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And these shoes are too goddamn tight! Susie hurls the shoes at Frank and stalks off barefoot. Jack is leaning against the wall, watching it all with amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice girl. ON Frank's expression we hear the OPENING NOTES of "New York, New York" and we see:

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: Susie and the boys performing it in one lounge after another, playing to increasingly enthusiastic audiences, no empty tables now. As the SONG ends, we CLOSE ON the cardboard stand-up, newly done over with a picture of Susie and an accompanying exclamation: "See the Sensational Susie Diamond!" As the FINAL CHORD sounds we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Frank, once again in the office of the supercilious Lloyd, waiting as he prepares their cash envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.  That's quite a girl you boys latched onto.  She a local?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Born and bred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky for you.  Well, there you go, guys.   Don't spend it all in one place.   Oh ... you want to count it, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We trust you, Lloyd.  You know that. Frank takes the envelope and begins to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, Frankie.  Since I've got you here... How's next week look for you guys? Frank glances at Jack, giving it to him.   Jack's eyes go cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll call you. As Lloyd's face drops, Jack and Frank step into the hallway and begin to walk slowly away, playing it cool, then glance at one another and begin to walk faster because they're about to burst out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time they reach the lobby, they are laughing, tripping across the carpet, out the front entrance and onto the sidewalk, where their voices explode in the night air and they begin to do a weird boyish waltz together, laughing giddily, until they see - standing under an awning, lighting a cigarette - Susie, watching them with raised eyebrows.  Jack and Frank, frozen in a clumsy embrace, quickly disengage and begin clearing their throats and squaring their cuffs.  Susie exhales a plume of smoke, studies them a moment, then smiles slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night, Bakers. As she turns away, Jack glances up, watching her trim shadow disappear down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gray and cold.  The streets swept with rain.   And once again the tentative piano: "JINGLE BELLS, jingle bells, jingle all the way.   Oh what fun it is to ride ... Oh what fun it is to ride ... Oh what fun..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Eddie are sitting in the waiting room: small and dirty and packed with pet owners and their animals. After a moment, a WOMAN with a clipboard appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barker. (no takers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jock Barker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing it's him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baker.  Jack Baker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  Bring him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Ed. Jack and Eddie follow the Woman down a corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should've brought a leash, Mr. Barker. The doctor doesn't like to be bitten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They never do, Mr. Barker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  In there. The Woman points Jack and Eddie into a small room. There is an examining table, a sink, and on the wall, a chart detailing the various breeds of dogs and cats. Jack glances around the room, then comes back to Eddie, who's staring up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shoulda brushed, pal. Just then, a MAN in a white coat breezes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, labradorus retreiverus.  Good fellows.   Quiet, but able to appreciate a good joke. Dr. Beasley pats Eddie on the side, then turns to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beasley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's our friend's problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're falling out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh.  That's not good.  Let's get him up here. Jack lifts Eddie up onto the table and Dr. Beasley opens Eddie's mouth for a look.  It doesn't take long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a take)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five's my guess.  Maybe more. Won't know till I get in there. (consulting his clipboard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave him now and you can pick him up in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there something you can give him?  A pill or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decay unfortunately doesn't limit itself to the denture, Mr. Baker. It spreads into his chest. Then the heart goes. We wouldn't want that, would we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How will he eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start him out on cottage cheese.   If you've got him on kibble, just soak it a few minutes.  Go down like pudding through a hot pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No bones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No bones. Jack looks at Eddie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Mr. Baker.  We'll knock him out. He won't feel a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think maybe I'll bring him back next week ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sooner we do this the better, Mr. Baker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack steps out onto the rainy street alone. He glances back at the vet's with second thought, then moves slowly off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack enters with a small grocery bag and opens the refrigerator.  A carton of cream, a few eggs -- there's not much there.  He takes a small container of cottage cheese from the grocery bag and places it on an empty shelf.  As he closes the refrigerator door, he glances around the apartment.  It is very still, very quiet.  He looks up at the ceiling absently, then walks over to the window and looks out.  There is a mug of coffee there on the sill.  He takes it and holds it in both hands for a moment, then places it back on the sill. He sits at the piano and runs his fingers lightly over the ivory, not making a sound, then places his hands on the keys and begins to play.  "Jingle Bells."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the front window, room has been made among the photographs for one of Susie.  Inside, Jack, Frank and Susie sit at a table, surrounded by empty coffee cups and cigarettes.  Frank has several slips of paper before him with names and dates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The twenty-third ... Yeah, here it is. We got the Carlton or the Plaza.  Four day turns. What do you think, Jack? Jack is staring out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, you with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Carlton's a dump.  No cover.  No minimum. And they water their drinks. It's strictly for the Fuller brush crowd. Susie, as she says this, is pouring sugar into her Coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it's,the Plaza then.   That brings us to the twenty-seventh.   We got the Avedon for three or the Park downtown for two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We take the Avedon, right?  Simple. Frank rubs his chin and looks at Jack.  Jack shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Park?  It's only two nights. Why throw away a night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because Blackie Carson books the Park and whenever we've needed a gig he's come through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (lifting her glass)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, for Blackie then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, I got a messsage yesterday from some guy looking for New Year's action.  Resort, upstate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (likes "resort')

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like a booking agent looking to book an easy fee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I figure.  Probably have us in a bed-and-breakfast playing to the owls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's legit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.  I'll call him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it collect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shuffling his slips)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it except for the first. We got the Sheraton, the Ambassador, or the Holiday Inn on Sixtieth.  All three-day turns. Frank looks at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Draw. Susie shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you guys used to decide what gig to take? Jack and Frank exchange a glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, well ... we flipped a coin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So find a dime.  Let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Frank step out-of the diner and turn their collars up against the chill.   Frank pulls on a pair of gloves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, it's gonna be mean this year.   Where're your gloves? Jack shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better take care of your fingers, little brother.   Buy yourself a case of arthritis and you won't be able to play 'Chopsticks.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take my chances. Frank pats his hands together and glances into the street

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something, huh?  All those bids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ... Well, I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna get a drink? Frank stops, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I... Little Frank's got strep. Donna's been up two nights making sure the rest of us don't get it. Jack nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay I'll see you tomorrow night then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. As Frank leaves, he takes a glance at his brother, then disappears around the corner.  A second later, Susie comes out of the diner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's egghead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His kid's sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (searching her purse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  It's hard figuring you two as brothers.  Seems like the hospital might've scrambled the babies somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes after our mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah,well, a11 I know is mother nature must be one crazy dame.  Shit. Jack offers his pack of cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-uh.  I never touch American cigarettes. (still searching)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's tomorrow again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stratford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice place.  Fulla velvet.  Even the bedspreads. (shaking the purse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn!  Two-fifty a pack and I go through 'em like toothpicks. Twelve-and-a-half cents a piece, you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paris Opals.  Twelve-and-a-half cents.  I sat down with a pencil and added it one day.  But I figure, if you're gonna be sticking something in your mouth, you might as well make it the best. (finding one)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, here's a lost soul. Jack lights it.  She takes a draw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm.  Like kissing a rose.  Well, au revoir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. (as she stops)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel like a cup of coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kidding?  We must've killed three pots in there.  Anyway, I gotta get home.  Rest the pipes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to walk you? Susie looks at Jack a little funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Thanks. She starts to move away, then stops and looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, listen.  You're not going soft on me, are you? I mean, you're not gonna start dreaming about me and waking up all sweaty and looking at me like I'm some kinda princess when I burp.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, that'd be too creepy. With us working together and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing personal -- Jack holds up his hand.  Susie just stands there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better hurry.  You're a nickel down on your cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack paces outside the veterinary clinic, rubbing his arms against the night's chill.  He glances up at the flickering sign over the building: "Twenty-Four Hour Emergency Care." Inside, a KID with deep-set eyes is bent over a magazine.  Jack hesitates then enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Jack glances around, ill at ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want something, pal?  If you're looking for a bathroom, try the Super Chief around the corner. The Kid goes back to his magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I, uh, left a dog here this morning. He needed some work on his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regular hours are eight to five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, I know.  I was just passing by. Thought I'd check in on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can check in on him tomorrow.   Between eight and five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, couldn't I take a look now? The Kid looks up at Jack with mild contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to know if he's okay. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name's Baker --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save it.  What's he look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black.  Labrador.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. they lay the dead ones out in the cold room.  I'll take a look. The Kid disappears into the back.  Jack stands frozen, watching the swinging door come to rest.  He looks like a man who, unexpectedly, finds a razor pressed to his neck.  He fumbles for a cigarette, but doesn't light it.  He waits.  A moment later, the door swings open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.  Just a couple poodles. Jack nods, then, moving stiffly, leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, he reaches into his coat and takes the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the floor, a long line of bowls, each containing a different concoction, all intended for the ailing Eddie Eddie, lying a few feet away, shows no interest.   In the kitchen, Jack is heating something up in a pan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried Cheerios this morning.   He didn't even get up. Maybe they took out the wrong teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just feeling sorry for himself.  This is it, pal.  Hear me? Two bucks a can. Jack dumps some brown slop into a bowl and places it next to the others.  Nina and he wait.  At first, nothing, the ... Eddie's eyes move.  His nose twitches.   His head lifts. Finally, he gets up and walks to the bowl.  He eats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chili.

dialogues.speaker: CITY
dialogues.text: draped in winter.  Dark skies, people lost in heavy coats, the city's battered Christmas decorations hung tenuously across traffic-clogged streets.  Over it all we hear "JINGLE BELLS," PLAYED for the first time completely through, hesitantly but without error. As the SONG ENDS, we are:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: watching Nina strike the final chord triumphantly. She turns to Jack, who's been listening from the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding to the ceiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna knock her dead, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All done up in reds and greens for Christams Eve. Jack, Frank and Susie -- each decked out in their own little Santa hats -- perform "Silver Bells" for the happy crowd. Jack, smoking a cigarette, will not be mistaken for Santa Claus, but Susie looks adorable. Frank just looks happy. As they finish, the crowd applauds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, now sans Santa hat, enters the bathroom off the lobby and finds Santa Claus standing in front of the mirror, fussing with his beard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You recognized me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a lucky guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very realistic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not buying it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, what can I say?  Dad must've had forty pounds on me. Jesus, you remember him being this big? Jack looks in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the line's growing weaker, little brother. Lucky for us there aren't any dragons left to slay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Frank step out into the lobby, thus giving a few people, Susie among them, the curious privilege of seeing Santa Claus exit a men's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to come out to the house tomorrow? The way the bookings been piling up, Donna's decided to really lay it on.  Turkey, stuffing, the whole bit.  Kitchen's so full of food you can hardly move.  We could use another appetite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, but I've got plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, but if you change your mind, let me know.  I gotta go get Ma in the morning anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well.  Ho, ho, ho.  You moonlighting at Macy's, Frank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the kids. (moving off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, you two.  Don't forget.  We leave the twenty-sixth. Frank pushes through the revolving door and steps out into the street in his Santa suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He do that every year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't the kids asleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why's he do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess in case one year they're not. Jack looks into Susie's eyes, then crosses to the door and exits.  Susie watches him go, then turns to the desk clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me a cab, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jack enters his apartment, he senses a presence in the room and looks over to the old phone booth.   Nina is sitting inside on the little stool, her head tilted against the glass.  Jack studies her a moment, then takes the carton of eggnog he's carrying into the kitchen and grabs a pair of glasses.  He pulls a chair over to the phone booth and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd the show go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  How'd yours go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so good. Jack looks at Nina's face, tender and young in the soft shadows of the booth.  After a moment, her eyes shift to the carton in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eggnog? Jack nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Hurley's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighty proof. What d'ya say? Think you can handle it? Nina nods. Jack begins to fill the two glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I stay here tonight?  Even if she comes here? Jack pauses a moment, then closes the carton and sets it aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. He hands Nina her glass, then takes his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Nina are standing in the middle of the room, looking down at something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? Eddie, outfitted in a brand new, spanking red dog sweater, stares up at Jack and Nina, wondering why he's the object of so much attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sporting his new sweater) make their way across an empty cemetery. Nina is swinging a bottle of whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were more flowers last year.  Mr. Rinaldi down at the drugstore says it's going to snow by New Year's.  Says he can feel it in his elbows. I hope it snows.  I want to make a snowman. You ever make a snowman, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I want to do.   I want to make a snowman. As they come to a plot of ground, they stop.   There are two matching headstones, one for Jack's father, fully engraved, and another for Jack's mother, bearing only her name.  Jack studies the plot a moment, then crouches before his father's marker: "ANDREW S. BAKER. Adoring Husband of Eleanor, Loving Father of Franklin and John." Jack brushes some dirt from the face of the stone, then stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now? Jack nods.  Nina uncaps the whiskey bottle and pours it onto the dead man's grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, Mr. Baker. They stand another moment, just looking, then turn away. As they begin to walk, Jack sees Eddie in his new sweater sniffing at a gravestone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Eddie.  Have some respect, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is sitting on a suitcase in front of his building. A moment later, Frank pulls the car up to the curb and Jack gets in.  Susie is sitting up front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, burning with the afterglow of a holiday spent with family, cheerfully maneuvers the car through the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. How was everyone's Christmas? Jack and Susie stare disconsolately out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too early, huh?  Well, there's coffee and donuts for whoever wants them.   How about a maple bar, Jack? Jack shakes his head and takes out a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Jack ... if you don't mind. Jack stares at the back of Frank's head, then puts the cigarette away. Susie takes a peek in the donut bag and looks a little sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, if anyone gets bored, Donna packed some travel games. They work wonders with the kids. Frank reaches under the seat and hands Susie a sack full of magnetic games, puzzles, and plastic cubes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two could play checkers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should just listen to the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.  It only plays static. Susie looks at the radio, then at the games in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long did you say it takes to get to this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is staring out the window at the winter landscape, an unlit cigarette dangling from his lip.   Susie is gnawing on a donut, deeply obsessed with an elaborate plastic puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any more coffee? Susie snaps out of her trance and shakes the Thermos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-uh.  Hey, what's this? Susie notices an old, leather-bound ledger.  Inside, there are hundreds of tiny entries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You play all these places?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baker's unabridged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, you fellas've made a lot of noise.  What's with the stars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virgins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Virgins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First times. Hey, look at this. A crepe-covered car surrounded by several other HONKING VEHICLES passes by.  Jack stares at the beaming newlyweds as they glide past his window, two kids starting life in a beat-up Eldorado covered with toilet paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's the last time we played a wedding, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two years ago.  March.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (consulting the ledger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's always right.  Go ahead.  Pick a virgin. Susie looks at Frank curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scanning the book)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.The Fantasy Inn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring out the window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: November.  '71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Day.  Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, he's got the gift.  Same with music. Hears it once and he's got it. Frank smiles into the rear view mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brilliant little brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hotel, done in a sort of King Arthur motif,is built right on the ocean.  Frank guides the car down a simulated cobblestone drive and the three get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you listen to that ocean? It's LOUD.  Frank takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how about this air? I'm telling you, a few days in this place'll put five years on your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smells like fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it smells like fish.   We're on the ocean. What'd you expect, Chanel number five?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smells like tuna number two to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's paradise.  That's what it is. Paradise. As Susie and Jack follow Frank up the drive, Jack notices the beat-up Eldorado in the parking lot, its toilet paper streamers blowing gently in the ocean breeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lobby is done in royal reds and blues and there are a lot of swords on the walls. Franks steps up to the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, we're the Fabulous Baker Boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to meet you.  I'm Terrific Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We're the entertainment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right, gotcha.  You got bags?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside.  Blue Chevy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ringing a bell)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cyril.  Chevy.  Blue.  Take 'em up to the Guinevere Suite. A lanky boy in velvet jodhpurs and high stockings ambles out for the bags.  Tom hands Frank the room keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right on the ocean, Mr. Baker. You can practically dangle your toes in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom wasn't kidding.  The immediacy of the ocean beyond the window is almost scary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe this?  I'm telling you, we're getting away with murder.  Two shows a night and the rest of the time we live like kings.  It's a crime. Jack stares at the ocean, then at the two beds placed side by side.  Suddenly Susie comes through the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, we're connected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Susie shrugs and returns to her room through the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we had separate rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening drawers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do.  She's got hers, we've got ours. Hey. Wash and Dries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we all had separate rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Jack.  It's not like it's the first time we've bunked together.  It'll be like when we were kids.  Relax.  Enjoy the view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, Frank and Susie are in the dining room, which, like their rooms, looks out over the ocean.   Dinner is over and they're well through a second bottle of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Charlie Steinway is my witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peggy Lee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was staying at the Grand downtown ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was April.  April seventeenth. That one I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were playing the lounge one night and she came in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pearls.  White gown.  Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank asked if she'd sit in for a song, she said yes, and we did a few bars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few bars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd she sing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People.' You think Streisand, right?   Hot that night.  Chills.   Through the whole audience.  I could hardly play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. You ever see her again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We got a picture, though.   One of the waitresses had a camera. (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, we were just kids.  That was something, wasn't it? Jack nods.  Frank shakes his head, still lost in the spring evening years before, then notices the newlyweds sitting across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, will you look at that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must've bought the same map we did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say we send a bottle over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it.  You're a romantic, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not true.  Besides, Jack's the romantic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just afraid to show it. Aren't you, little brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have some more wine, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea. (lifting his glass)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Peggy Lee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, standing, dressed in pajamas. Jack is staring out the window at the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm putting my stuff on the right, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figure that way we won't get confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless you want the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you take the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We might as well do the towels the same way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just figure things'll go smoother, you know, if we have it all worked out from the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if it doesn't work out, let me know.  I'm,flexible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Frank nods and moves to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; re: the bathroom light)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You leaving that on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna be here a week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're gonna leave it on. Every night.  For a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  You mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I mean, I always did it as a kid. I figured it was no big deal.  Is it?  A big deal? Jack just stares at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I didn't know.  I mean, I always did it as a kid. It was never a big deal then.  Was it? Jack just stares at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well.  You want me to turn it off? Jack just stares at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll turn it off. Jack turns back to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.  It's no big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning.  Jack and Frank are standing in a huge dining room, appraising two elegant grands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're beauties, huh? Jack steps up to one and runs his hand over the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reminds me of those Steinways Willie used to have. Frank taps a few notes on his piano, humming happily. Jack begins to echo his brother's notes, listening. After a moment, Frank notices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short, stubby LITTLE MAN in a charcoal suit strides into the dining room, followed by Terrific Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, gentlemen.  I'm Mr. Daniels, the manager.  I believe I've spoken to one of you on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offering his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'd be me, sir.  Frank Baker.   This is my brother Jack. Jack, slouched against the piano, smoking, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom here tells me there's a problem with the pianos.  We were assured they were in tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'm afraid I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are in tune.  But not with each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that important?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, well ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  It's important. Frank glances nervously at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom, who're we dealing with on these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Mr. Reynolds, sir.  But he's gone on vacation. I called this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, gentlemen, I don't know what to say.   Not being a musician myself I find it difficult to grasp the magnitude of this.  I don't suppose there's any way you could just ... accommodate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accommodate?  I don't think I know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think what Mr. Daniels is trying to say, Jack, is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we let Mr. Daniels tell us what he's trying to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assure you, Mr. Baker, no offense is intended. I simply mean, well, we're not a symphony, are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank dogs Jack down a hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack ... Jack ... You're acting like a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's your problem, Frank.  You get around one of these assholes and you turn into a fucking three-year-old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you?  So the piano's a little out of tune.  So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, can't you hear it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I never hear it! (shaking his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.  Sometimes.  I don't know. But I won't let it bother me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't it matter to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What matters to me is we've got the six easiest nights we've had in ten years.   So 'Tie a Yellow Ribbon' sounds a little flat.   So what?  Nobody's gonna hear it, Jack.  Nobody. So why should you care?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I can hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then stuff cotton in your ears, because come six o'clock we're gonna walk into that dining room with smiles on. Understand, little brother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is adjusting his tie in the bathroom mirror. Jack, sitting at the window, his foot up against the glass, drinks from a flask as the sky above the ocean goes dark.  After a moment, Susie enters wearing a little tuxedo of her own and begins to brush her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, fellas.  What's the word? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with you two?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack woke up on the wrong side of the bottle. Susie looks at Jack.  Then Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0-kay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jack, Frank and Susie perform "Strangers in the Night, dozens of couples move slowly on the dance floor, while others sit at candle-lit tables, sipping cocktails. As the song ends, the couples applaud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, thank you. (as applause dies)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Susie and Jack and I only just arrived here yesterday, but already the people here at the King Corporation's Moorish Manor have made us feel, well, a part of the family. And it's their hope that, before you leave, everyone of you will feel a part of that family also.  So, if during-the next few days, we should happen to pass one another in the hallway or in the lobby or wherever ... don't be a stranger. Stop.  Say hello.  Introduce yourself.  Because here, there are no strangers, only friends.   And family.  Right, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  I love you, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.  I just wanted to say it. Frank stares incredulously at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, well, I love you, too, Jack. (moving quickly along)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. Susie.  How 'bout it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got another song for us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah.  I gotta bunch of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then ... shall we?

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: Frank corners Jack as they exit the stage. Susie looks around nervously to see if anyone's watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Frank.  All that talk about family. I just got emotional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you say you love me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't happen again.  Scout's honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with you guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone needs to grow up.  I won't take it, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you will. Jack pushes past Frank and leaves.   Frank watches him go, then turns to leave himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Middle of the night.  Jack, fully clothed, is sitting on the rim of the tub, smoking. Susie enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry.  With the light always on, it's hard to tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. (the cigarette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In and out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the waves.  God's music, my mother used to say. She was crazy for the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I wish God would go a little easy on the trumpets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's egghead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a baby. You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In and out. Jack nods.  Susie looks at him carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want, I got a pack in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.  I never touch French cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning.  As Jack passes through the lobby, he hears the plaintive PLINKING of a PIANO.  Curious, he goes to the dining room and peers in.   The tables have yet to be set for the evening and, except for Frank, the room is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it look like I'm doing? I'm tuning a goddamn piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, really.  I don't want you to be unhappy, Jack.  If you say it's out of tune, it's out of tune. Jack smiles to himself and crosses the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long you been at it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half-hour.  Once I finish this octave I'm gonna get breakfast.  You see what's on the buffet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stopped serving two hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hours ago!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time flies, huh? Frank looks despairingly at the pianos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could give you a hand.  If you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Frank are eating lunch.  Frank has a tiny stack of blue cards he's perusing.   He holds one out to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you make that?  Paruchi? Jack nods.  Frank continues to go through the cards as he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't seen Susie, have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wonder what she's up to. I never see her.  Makes me nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a big girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, she's our girl now.  I think we better keep an eye on her.  There's trouble there. (another card)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, listen to this.  Ethel and Bert Lane.   Married seventy-five years.  You believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dedications.  I came up with the idea on the road. See, every morning the maids drop one of these cards in each room.  The guest fills out the card, leaves it at the front desk, and that night we play it.  Daniels went crazy for the idea. (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's not all.  Last night, after the nine o'clock, he corners me, right, and starts asking about our availability.  Like he wants to line something up. I think he's got a hard-on for Susie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Frank jumps.  A WOMAN in a bright flowered gift shop dress pokes her head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to interrupt, but when I saw you sitting here, I just had to come over.  Florence Simmons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh ... Frank Baker.  This is my brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know, I know.  My husband and I saw you play last night and it's the most remarkable thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean you. (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a brother-in-law who looks exactly like you. Exactly.  You don't happen to have a Huckleberry in your family tree, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's frightening.  You could be his twin. Of course, he doesn't have your talent.  Musically, I mean.  He sharpens things for a living.  Lawn mower blades, kitchen knives, anything with an edge. Can imagine? Jack is having a hard time imagining Florence Simmons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, anyway, I just had to make sure there was no relation.  You play wonderfully.  Both of you. Florence Simmons gives a little flutter of a wave and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thinking there's someone who looks like you, walking around the street somewhere. (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonder if I saw him I'd think it was you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is standing on the walkway that encircles the hotel, watching the waves tumble into one another.   As he starts to take out a cigarette, he notices Florence Simmons standing a few yards away with a camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just know my sister won't believe me. Do you mind? Jack shakes his head and Florence starts to aim the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really hate to impose.  It's just that the resemblance is so extraordinary. (focusing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if you could turn this way so your face isn't in the shadows. As Jack turns, he glances over Florence's swaying shoulder and sees Susie and a man standing at the other end of the walkway.  They are leaning into the wind, her hair blowing free, brushing the man's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say cheese. The camera clicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotcha.  Would you like a copy for yourself?  The hotel develops. Jack glances away from Susie and the man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. ON Jack's expression APPLAUSE is heard and a moment later we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That evening.  The trio has just finished a song and those on the dance floor are clapping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  You know, before we came out here this evening, Susie and Jack and I were looking over your dedications and something struck us. Susie and Jack look at Frank as if they have no idea what he's talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We realized that, well, we're really not so different from one another after all.  Oh sure, we may be at different points in our journey, but we all travel pretty much the same road. And so, with that in mind, we'd like to introduce you to two very special couples.  First, married for all of two days, please say hello to Helen and Bud Wilson.  Helen.  Bud. Those standing on the dance floor applaud as the young couple from the beat-up Eldorado make their way to the front of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now, our second couple.  I'm talking about Ethel and Bert Lane, ladies and gentlemen.  Now, Ethel and Bert would be upset with me if I told you they'd been married for fifty years.  Why? Because, ladies and gentlemen, Ethel and Bert Lane have been married for seventy-five years! The audience lets go with an audible "ooh" and applauds enthusiastically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethel, Bert.  Get up here and show these kids how it's done. A path is cleared and a tiny couple begins to make their way to the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't they a sight? They are indeed, and a sight slower getting to the dance floor than Frank anticipated. He nods to Jack and they launch into "The Anniversary Waltz," but have to keep repeating the opening passage while they wait for Ethel and Bert.  Finally, everyone on the dance floor steps back and, with some help from a few waiters, who slide a section of tables out of the way, Ethel and Bert Lane begin to dance in the center of the room, slowly but wonderfully, while the younger couple whirls around them like a youthful satellite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is sitting in the bathroom again, smoking.  He hears Susie's door open, then VOICES -- hers and a man's.  He puts out his cigarette in the sink and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning.  Frank, the early bird, is returning to the room with a newspaper under his arm. Whistling happily, he rounds the corner just in time to see a man exit Susie's room.  Astonished, then outraged, he goes to Susie's door and knocks sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget your tie, handsome ... Frank!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to tell me what the hell's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just saw a man walk out of your room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case you've forgotten, we're being paid to be here.  So it might be nice if you conducted yourself with a certain amount of decency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decency?  Hey listen, pal ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You listen.  I had my doubts about you from the beginning

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Frank and Susie turn.  Jack is standing in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you trying to do?  Wake up the whole goddamn hotel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just having a little discussion about morality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some discussion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just saw a man walk out of your room!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's with the hotel.  I called him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a leak in the bathroom. He fixed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was wearing a suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had to come quickly.  It was a big leak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come I didn't hear anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a heavy sleeper, Frank. You've always-been a heavy sleeper. (looking at Susie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unlike me. Frank looks at Jack, then Susie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I ... If I jumped to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. The three stand there awkwardly for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... Frank shrugs lamely and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, he comes on like a hurricane in the morning, doesn't he? Jack just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, thanks for sticking your head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, business is business. He turns to leave.  Susie's eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't business.  It was pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just dinner and dance, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, Frank and Susie are sitting at a table in the smaller dining room.  It is conspicuously quiet.   The main course seems to be a conscious attempt to ignore each other.  Finally, Susie looks at Frank.   Then Jack.  Then out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paradise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Frank's room.  It is New Year's Eve, just before show time, and Jack and Frank are in their tuxes.  Frank is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Daddy promises.  I'll bring you one of the little glasses, how's that?  Just like Grandma has.   It has a picture of the hotel on it and everything ... No, honey, they don't sell puppies here ... Who? ... Well, we'll see.  Let me talk to Mommy, okay?... Okay,sweetheart.  Happy New Year. (waits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, honey.  She says Angela Secoli got a puppy for Christmas.  Explain to her why we can't ... I don't know, tell her you're allergic ... It's not lying. Well, okay, it is lying, but ... All right, then tell her I'll explain it ... He what? ... No kidding? Without the training wheels? (affected by this)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's great.  Tell him, tell him. I can't wait to see ... No, no new bike.  Maybe for his birthday ... Okay.  Listen, honey, I have to go.We're on in ten minutes ... Yeah, Happy New Year ... I love you ... Frank sets the phone down and stares at it.   Jack studies him a moment, then Frank suddenly claps his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's go.  The public waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mass of swarming, jubilant people.  The voices are high and loud and there's not a hand without a champagne glass.  Couples lean into one another intimately, dancing gaily between the tables, toasting strangers without hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling to be heard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, everyone.  This is it. Let's hear it.  Ten.  Nine ... Gradually, the entire room joins the chant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight.  Seven.  Six.  Five. Four.  Three.  Two!  ONE!

dialogues.speaker: HAPPY NEW YEAR
dialogues.text: There is a blizzard of confetti as people scramble to find that certain someone to kiss in the new year.   In this moment, Jack, Frank and Susie find themselves oddly removed from the frantic cheer below them, their presence suddenly unnecessary, forgotten.   Finally, Susie walks over to Frank and gives him a kiss, then goes to Jack.  They hesitate, then kiss lightly, pulling away and glancing awkwardly into each other's eyes.  Frank sounds the first chord of "Auld Lang Syne" and Susie looks away from Jack and returns to her place on the stage.  As she begins to sing, the others in the room, all intimate friends for one brief moment, begin to sing with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lest old acquaintances be forgot ... As the voices slowly fade, they are joined by the sound of the OCEAN until the ocean is all we hear and we see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, lying on his bed in the dark.  He opens his eyes, squinting against the light from the bathroom, then glances over to Frank's bed and detects the outline of a body in the darkness.  Swinging his legs over the side, he sits up on the edge of the bed and rubs his eyes Suddenly there is a rustle of blankets and the shadow in the next bed shifts, falling into the shaft of light cast from the bathroom.  It is a little boy.  Startled, Jack stares at the sleeping boy, then hears movement in the bathroom.  Rising slowly, he walks to the bathroom and gently eases the door open a few inches.  Inside, swimmin murkily in the steamy mirror, is the reflection of a man. His back is to Jack, but Jack can see that the man is shaving.  As Jack lets his gaze drop to the floor, he see that water is dripping off the man's pant cuffs and gathering in pools on the bathroom floor ... Jack wakes up.  He stares at the ceiling, listening to the waves, then lifts his head and looks to the bathroom.  It is dark. Turning, he glances at Frank's bed.  It's empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark and soundless.  Balloons, streamers and the other debris of revelry cover the tables and floor like snow.   Frank is sitting at the window, drinking as he stares at the ocean.  As Jack crosses the room, he looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, well, if it isn't the lad with the golden ear. Happy New Year, little brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing down here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celebrating.  Join me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're wrong.  It's just beginning. Come on, have a drink.   Show your big brother how it's done. Frank pours him a glass.  Jack notices the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Expensive hangover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gift.  Courtesy of our courteous hotel manager, Mr. Daniels. (toasting Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We, dear brother, are a fucking smash. (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.  They want us back.  Easter.  It seems they have this egg hunt every year.  Only not for kids. Adults.  They stuff these plastic eggs with Timexes and little certificates for free Mai Tais and everyone has a grand time crawling around on the front lawn.  Then afterwards, they have a dance.  An egg dance.  Everyone comes dressed in a different colored shell and at the end of the evening they crack themselves open.  It's our job to separate the yolks from the whites. Slippery business. Frank smiles as he takes a swallow of his drink, then leans his head back, staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I've never kissed my wife on New Year's. Not once in twelve years. Jack studies Frank as he stares at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Holmby has a chandelier like that doesn't it? With the blue glass. Jack looks up at the chandelier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Royal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  The Royal.  When's the last time we were there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couple years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: February?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: April.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  It's incredible how you do that.  Remember things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A useless talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drove me crazy when we were kids. The way you never looked at the music. Miss Simpson would just play it and ... Frank snaps his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were simple songs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for me.  I still have to look at the music sometimes, you know that?  Otherwise, I forget. I just forget.  But you.  You never forget. Ever. (turning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how come you couldn't remember Ma's birthday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you.  It's a useless talent. Frank studies Jack a moment, then stares out at the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, the old man would've loved this view, wouldn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always think of him on New Year's.   How he used to pour us each half a can of beer. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always threw up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and you drank yours like it was orange juice. He loved that about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was just having fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was like you'd passed some test, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just a can of beer, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but he told you things.  He never told me anything.  Even though I was the oldest.   It was always you two, running off, doing things together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could've come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could've.  But he didn't want me to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're making things up, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe so. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever go back there?  Where it happened. Jack stares at the angry SEA, LOUD even through the thick glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning.  Jack is sitting outside the hotel, watching HELEN and BUD WILSON pack up the Eldorado.   The streamers, by now turned to mush, cling like oatmeal to the car's exterior.  After a moment, Frank exits with a little bag from the gift shop and pulls out a tiny souvenir shot glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want one? Jack shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah well, the kids'll break a couple anyway. Suddenly, across the parking lot, the voices of the newlyweds are heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the keys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to drive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my goddamn car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's our goddamn car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Bud hesitates, then makes a rush for his wife, but she's too quick and runs to the other side of the car. Frustrated, he begins to run around the car like a madman, trying to catch her.  Finally, when he gets close, she darts off, sprinting across the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll warm up the car.

dialogues.speaker: OVERVIEW
dialogues.text: Cold, dark, dangerous, but somehow looking quite appealing after a week in paradise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trio, looking road-weary, is parked in front of Jack's building.  It is very late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That takes care of this week.  The tenth we got the Sheraton, the sixteenth we're at the Capri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tenth's out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't make the tenth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean maybe you should check with us before you go off and book us a month in advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be reasonable, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I play two hundred nights a year with you, Frank. How much more reasonable you expect me to be? Jack gets out of the car.  Frank shakes his head in exasperation, then looks to Susie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you?  Got a Bar Mitzvah this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack lets himself in and closes the door quietly. In the darkness he can make out Nina and Eddie, curled up on the couch, asleep.  Above them, hung carefully on a string, are some paper letters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a lounge whols basic decor makes abundant use of several historical eras but which might best be described as Modern Pilgrim, Jack, Susie and Frank perform "Feelings," while waiters in huge Paul Revere hats pass in and out of view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feelings ... Wo wo wo ... Feelings ... Wo wo wo ... Feelings ...

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Jack, Frank and Susie exit the lounge to applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't sing it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That song.  I can't sing it anymore. I'm gonna get sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you talking about?  They love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna throw up, Frank.  I mean it.   Let's drop it for the ten o'clock, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as to a child)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie.  It's one more show.  One more time.  That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And two more times tomorrow night, and two more times the next night, and the next night and the next night and the next night.  Frank, I can't sing that fucking song anymore! She's yelling.  The kitchen workers are glancing over. Jack studies her as she tries to calm herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need some air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few minutes later.  Jack comes out of the hotel and sees Susie pacing.   He sits down and watches her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna wear down those heels if you don't give it a rest. She stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax.  We'll drop the song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess I got a little scattered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a shitty  song. Susie nods and looks up at the glittering hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do it? Every night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Practice. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are worse songs, you know. Not many, but a few. Susie nods.  Jack studies her.  Something's on her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen... (looks into his eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A record is spinning on Jack's phonograph as the sun goes down outside his window.  As we MOVE AWAY FROM the phonograph and PAST the window, we FIND Jack at the piano, playing along with the record, lost in concentration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie is working on a Paris Opal, pacing, occasionally glancing up at Jack's apartment, where the MUSIC can be heard FAINTLY.  After a moment, she drops her cigarette on the sidewalk.  There are half a dozen others already there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The record finishes, but the needle doesn't pick up, bumping into the label.  Jack glances at the clock next to him and gets up.  He puts on a jacket, then takes a pair of gloves and pulls them on carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jack comes out of his building, Susie stops pacing, surprised.  Jack, wearing the same look of concentration he had at the piano, doesn't see her and turns down the other end of the street.  Susie starts to call after him, but stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is gone now and the moon is in the sky.   We see the hot neon exterior of a tiny jazz club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is sitting in the shadows near the stage, where a trio is playing.  He has a drink in front of him, but it is untouched.  After a moment, the trio finishes and the pianist, a huge black man named HENRY, nods to the applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  As most of you know, we like to shake things up here every so often just to keep you people on your toes.  So I'm gonna take a little rest, grab myself a drink, and let an old friend sit in.  He drops by about once a year just to keep his hands clean.  Ladies and gentlemen.   Jack Baker. Jack rises to polite applause and shakes Henry's hand.   As he settles behind the piano, he sits for a moment, not moving, then nods to the two men behind him.  As they begin to play, we recognize the music from the record.   Jack waits, then brings his hands to the keys.  As he plays, his face is suddenly calm.  Peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later.  Jack comes out of the club and into the night, lighting a cigarette as he moves up the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were good. Jack stops.  Susie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can keep the beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better than that. Jack's face goes a little cold, but he says nothing, beginning to walk again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd I say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I said was you were good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. You don't know good. All right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means you wouldn't know good if it came up and fucked you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's make a deal.  You shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I saw the other people! And they knew you were good! You were good, goddamnit! Jack studies Susie, then glances off.  For a moment, they just stand on the corner, not talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you wanna get a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nina?
