dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Nina?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friend?  What's she look like? Maybe I can help you find her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's four feet tall.  Ed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed? How many people live here? Eddie walks around the couch and looks curiously at Susie.  Jack moves to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to make him some chili. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light from a weak lamp, lots of shadows, as romantic as Jack's apartment will ever get.  Outside the window, the city looks like a thousand jewels, gleaming. Susie cradles a drink in her hand as she moves slowly about the room, slipping, in and out of the shadows as if they were veils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like diamonds, huh?  I never get over it.   When I was a little girl, my mama'd stand me before the window and tell me to close my eyes and make a wish.Like I could reach out and grab all the lights of the city and string them into-a necklace for myself.  She'd take my hand and when she closed her eyes, I don't know, it was like she really believed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you didn't close your eyes? She looks surprised by the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I guess I didn't trust the night like she did. Susie finishes her drink and sets it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me have a cigarette, will you?   All of mine are down there on the sidewalk. Jack looks at her curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long story. Jack gives her an American cigarette and lights it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I saw you guys once. You and Frank.  At the Roosevelt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must've been a cheap date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soap convention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, they got a convention for everything. At least he was clean.  Boy, the guys I met when I was with the service, you wouldn't believe.  The older ones, they were okay.  Nice.  Polite.  Pulled the chair out for you.  But the younger ones ... (shaking her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama used to say, dance with a man once, but if you can feel calluses on his fingers, don't dance with him again.  She thought she had it all figured out.   But she wasn't so smart.  There are killers with palms like a baby. Susie takes a long draw and blows the smoke out slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't so bad, though.  I'd get a nice piece of steak, flowers, sometimes even a gift.  Usually whatever the guy was into.  Got a socket set once.   Believe it?  The guy looked like held just given me four dozen roses. (almost wistful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I stayed at the Hartford once.  You should see the rooms.  All satin and velvet.  And the bed.   Royal blue, trimmed in lace clean as snow.  Hard to believe sleeping in a room like that don't change your life.  But it don't.  The bed may be magic, but the mirror isn't.  You wake up the same old Susie. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't always, you know.  If I liked the guy ... Susie looks at Jack, but he just takes a drink.  She looks out the window again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wish the sun would never come up. She stares at the lights another moment, then turns and nods to the phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's this? Jack frowns, takes another drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: History.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father proposed to my mother in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding? It's a small phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The both of them?  In there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He called her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. So what's it doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sending me home? Jack locks eyes with Susie, then glances away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'd been out dancing all night and he took her to the train station -- she lived over in Brookhaven.  Usually held ride with her, but this time he didn't.  Anyway, he starts walking home, only as he's walking he starts getting nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nervous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time he gets to the corner newstand, he's got her meeting some rich guy on the train, the rich guy's asked her to marry him, and he's reading about it in the morning edition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had a mind that escalated things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He calls her, asks her to marry him, she thinks he's crazy, he asks her again, she still thinks he's crazy but says yes anyway, and the next thing you know he's got his brothers down there and they're tearing the thing right off the curb. Susie blinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Maybe he thought some rich guy was gonna try and call her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.  But I still don't see how ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma didn't want it around.  After.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Jack glances out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing, carefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank said you saw him die. Jack glances up quickly, surprised.  He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank said ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank wasn't 'there. Susie stops, looks down.  Jack studies her for a moment, then decides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He took me out to the docks one day.  We did that a lot.  There were other places, but he loved the ocean. He'd worked boats as a kid.  Never got rid of it. It was always in him.  He'd drink a little when we'd go.  If he drank enough, he'd do this funny Irish jig. To make me laugh. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drank a lot that day. Susie studies Jack as he stares into his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a lot of wind.  He was up on this cargo shelf, right over the ocean.  And he started to do the jig.  One minute he was there ... (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was a joke at first. He did things like that.  Games. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was laughing when it happened. Jack stares at the glass in his hands, then glances up and catches Susie looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got pretty eyes, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's bed.  In the darkness, we see Susie's profile, her eyes looking up toward the ceiling.  Jack's body falls slowly across her and he kisses her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Eddie, wearing his Christmas sweater, sleeping on the fire escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie is dressed, sitting at the piano, staring out the window as she absently hits a key.  She is smoking one of Jack's cigarettes.  Distracted.  Jack comes to the doorway and watches her.  Plink.  Plink.  Plink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta move 'em around if you want to play a song. Susie starts, looks at her hand on the piano, pulls it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Hi.  Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if you want to leave...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe ... No. God, I hate these cigarettes! Susie throws the cigarette out the window, then looks down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.  I think I started a fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If our feet get hot, you grab the piano. Susie smiles weakly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you go.  I'll see you tomorrow night at the Ambassador. Susie doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I followed you last night.  I mean, I was here.  Outside.  I was about to come up when you came out. Jack waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reason I came by ... I couldn't tell Frank... I'm leaving.  The act. Susie stares up at Jack, but he says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a ... I met this guy at the resort.  He liked my voice.  And, it's ... He thinks I can sell cat food just by singing about it.  Can you believe it? Susie tries a laugh.  Jack nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can always get another girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks out window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's always another girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Frank stand in a lounge, talking to NICK, the manager.  Busboys move in and out, preparing the room for the evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sick?  How sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So she's got a few sniffles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor's orders. Nick frowns, looking at the two pianos across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got no right springing this on me, Frankie.   It's unethical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Nick.  You want us to pack up, we'll pack up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I gonna do?  Put a record player out there? (exiting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad, Frankie.  Bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Frank)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just until we find another girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cancel, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to know how much I got tied up in deposits with Willie?  We're in for three weeks solid, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better give her pneumonia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Frank find themselves in the back room of Willie's again.  They do not look happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember me? Jack and Frank look up.  A girl in a yellow and black dress is in the doorway.  She looks like a bumblebee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monica.  Monica Moran.  I came in the last time you guys were looking for a singer. (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perseverance.  First rule of show business. Jack and Frank just stare at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bought a book.  That's what it says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is looking at a list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got the Roosevelt on Thursday, the Park in a couple of weeks.  Larry Shelton said he'd let me know by Friday on the Ambassador.  That's it. Frank folds the paper carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got some calls out.  Things that might be good for us. Frank looks over at Jack for the first time.  He's leaning against the building, staring at his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll try for a girl again next week. Jack nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  Well, the Roosevelt then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once grand, now dark and dusty looking.  A small crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, my brother and I have been playing together, gosh, I don't know.  Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-eight years. No response.  Bored, brutally indifferent faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, uh, back then it was, uh, a little different.  We were just kids.  Just about the only one who would listen to us was the family cat, Cecil.  We must've shaved three lives off old Cecil, huh, Jack? Frank laughs and his voice, eerily magnified by the microphone, is the only sound in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; hanging tough)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, anyway.  It's nice to be back here in the Roosevelt Room, because this has always been ... Frank falters as he sees Mrs. Baker enter the lounge and seat herself at a table in the back of the room. Jack follows Frank's eyes and spots her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a very special place for Jack and I. (recovering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And tonight we'd like to open with a very special song.  It's the song my mother and father danced  to the night they were married.  This is for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack watches as Frank gives Mrs. Baker a hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should've told us you were coming, Ma.   We would've come and got you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spur of the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what'd you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thrilling. (glancing at Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience was a little off tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few empty tables.  It's cozier.   Besides, Mel Torme couldn't fill this place on a Wednesday night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you're,right.  Well, what do you say we get a little midnight snack?   Theo's should still be open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.  You boys are tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we're not.  Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired.  Really.  I should get home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just call me a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab?  Ma, come on.  My car's just a half block down.  You wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Frank dashes out of the lobby.  Jack and Mrs. Baker watch him go, then turn to each other.  Mrs. Baker smiles awkwardly, then surveys the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful, isn't it? The brocade on the walls has faded and the chairs - once covered with velvet, now with a cheap imitation - look old and dowdy, but the room still maintains an elegant dignity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was quite,a place once.  After the war.  On Friday nights they had dances in the ballroom upstairs.  It was beautiful.  Crystal chandeliers. White tablecloths.  Orchids floating in the punch bowls... It was a wonderful place to be young. Jack watches his mother as her eyes pass over the room. After a moment, she nods toward the lounge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It went well tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank works hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads, I follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the way it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He mentioned you had a girl for a while.  A singer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a while.  She left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, it's probably best. No sense bringing someone else in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose. Mrs. Baker glances into the lounge, at the two pianos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny.  Watching tonight, I was remembering when you were young. How I used to stand in the kitchen, listening to the two of you practice while I did the dishes. (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My two little radios.  Sometimes I'd stop and go to the door and just watch.  Sometimes your father would too. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He liked to listen to you play. Did you know that? Jack shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You miss him, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a long time, Ma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I supposed you still have that old phone booth. Jack nods.  Mrs. Baker smiles, then it fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His love scared me, you know.  The day he died he left a flower on my pillow. Jack looks puzzled.  Suddenly his mother reaches out and very gently touches her fingers to his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look so like him. They stand like this for a moment, connnected, then Frank steps in from the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your limo's ready, Ma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Mrs. Baker takes her hand from Jack's face and turns away.  Just before she exits, she looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, walking home, turns a corner and suddenly stops. Across the street, talking to a man, is Susie.  She says a few words to the man, then touches him lightly on the arm and begins to walk away.  Jack watches her retreat, then follows, moving quicker as he draws close.  As he reaches her, he gently touches her elbow and she turns. Not Susie.  The woman stares at Jack, startled.   For a moment, he doesn't move.  Finally, he lets go of her elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few nights later.  Frank guides the car through wet city streets.  It's two AM and raining hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not getting paid then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. We get nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, Jack.  It's a telethon. No one gets a cent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Some disease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What disease?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a disease, Jack.  We're against it. It's not a moral decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (another pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What channels it on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventy-one

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventy-one?  What's seventy-one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A channel.   It's just a little further down the dial, that's all. Look, it's publicity.  Publicity's publicity.  Right? Jack stares at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Frank make their way down a hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy said to find Studio E and turn right.  What's that say? Suddenly, a rapid-fire THUMPING SOUND resounds through the corridor.  As Jack and Frank turn, they see a huge YOUTH in a wheelchair dribbling a basketball toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fast break! Jack and Frank step back and watch the kid one-wheel it around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it's that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry Lewis need not fear.  This is strictly a tin foil and crepe paper operation. Along one wall is the "phone bank," monitored by a few sleepy volunteers, and opposite in makeshift bleachers, is the audience.  A huge tote boa set on rolling astors, is next to the phones.  The total, at 2:15 AM, is $1125.38. As Jack and Frank enter, the kid in the wheelchair is doing basketball tricks before the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This must be it.  I'll see when we're on. Frank leaves. Jack glances around the studio like he's walked into a nightmare.  At the phone bank, a heavyset MAN in a sweatshirt and a cap, looks over.  Both the sweatshirt and the cap have "Earl" printed on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the magician?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  What do you do? Jack points to the pianos across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hopeful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two at a time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother and I. One each.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating the kid in the wheelchair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with the kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knee.  Tore it up against St. Anthony's.  Right before the accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accident?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fire.  The way we're going we'll be lucky to buy a carton of jockstraps, let alone a new gym. As Jack registers this, Earl's PHONE RINGS.  Frank returns and gestures to the kid in the wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on after Meadowlark. (seeing Jack's face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me?  Are you fucking kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're playing for a goddamn gymnasium!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Before Jack can further enlighten Frank, the kid in the wheelchair rolls off and a guy in a cheap rented tux strides in front of the camera.  He's VINCE NANCY, the host.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hear it for our own Jimmy Marshall, shall we? The audience applauds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As most of you'know, young Jimmy put a nasty twist on that knee trying to win-one for good ol' Grant High this year.  Luckily, the doctors tell us Jimmy'll be able to play next season.  That is ... if there is a next season. (Uncle Sam)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where you come in.  Pick up that phone.   Make a donation.  Let's keep our kids off the streets and in the gym where they belong. Applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  Well, friends, what can I say about our next guest? (consulting a card)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He, uh, they, uh, we are very pleased to have with us two of the most respected men in the musical entertainment field.  I think you'll agree with me when I tell you we're in for a real treat when I say that we have with us ... the Fabulous Bunker Boys!  Come on out here guys. Vince gestures grandly to the left and Jack and Frank enter from the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoops, there they are.  Hey, nice suits, fellas. (to camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I know a lot of you amateur musicians out there are going to want to rap with these guys and don't worry.  Right after they finish up here, they're going to be manning the phones.  Maybe we can even convince them to raffle off a few piano lessons if we're lucky.  What do you think? The audience applauds.  Jack glares at Frank.  He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, all right then.  What are we waiting for?  Take it away, guys. Jack and Frank poise their hands over their pianos and begin to play.  As the music rises, the studio becomes very quiet, almost still.  Unfortunately, Jack and Frank are barely through the opening passage when a thunderousl LOUD BELL begins to RING.  Suddenly, Vince steps out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh oh.  We know what that means, don't we?  It's time to turn the board over. (to Jack, Frank)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid you fellas'll just have to wait a minute.   Let's bring out the board. Two post-pubescent giants roll out the tote board right in front of Jack and Frank.   Jack looks positively homicidal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack ... Jack kicks out the piano bench and starts to leave.   Then, seeing the kid in the wheelchair, he grabs the basketball and fires it at Vince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a fucking creep, you know that.  I oughta kick your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, you're on television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Frank. Earl of the sweatshirt and cap puts his hand on Jack's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say we go for a walk, pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your hand off me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, friend.  I can smell it on you.   Get yourself a cup of coffee.  You'll forget what you're angry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go fuck yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes go hard)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a real tough guy when the ladies are around, aren't you, Ace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see any ladies here. Except maybe you. That does it.  Earl takes hold of Jack's collar and starts to-wrestle him roughly toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, leave him alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do your brother a favor and have his mouth sewn up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a lousy dancer, Earl.  Don't you know the man's supposed to lead? Earl shoves Jack into the hallway, hard.   Jack stumbles back against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you think you are, asshole? Liberace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack walks down the street, mindless of the rain.   Frank follows a few yards behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack.  We just,passed the car. Jack.  This is a tuxedo.  Three hundred dollars. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna talk to me?  Or is this Jack's famous silent act?  Look, it was for publicity.   Do you understand?  Publicity. Jack stops and stares at Frank incredulously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What-are you?  A fucking moron? It's three o'clock in the morning, Frank.  Who's watching?  Your wife? Maybe you can get us a gig playing Little Frank's birthday party. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look.  I didn't know when we were going to be on until yesterday.  What was I supposed to do?   I had the pianos anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Basketballs, Frank.  You had us playing for basketballs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  I should've checked it out.  I screwed up.  But that doesn't mean you walk out in the middle of a gig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't professional, Jack.  It was a stunt.   A stupid-ass stunt. Jack just stares at Frank, as if looking at a stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening to you, Frank?  You been kissing ass so long you're starting to like it?  You let that guy turn us into clowns tonight.  We were always small time, but we were never clowns, Frank.   What's happened to your dignity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dignity?  Who the hell are you to talk about dignity? Frank suddenly steps forward and reaches into Jack's jacket, coming away with a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This where you get your dignity, Jack?   This is where you get your courage? Jack tries to grab the bottle but Frank holds it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, let's do it straight for once, shall we? Frank tosses the BOTTLE into the street, where it SHATTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me explain something to you, little brother.   See, I've got people who depend on me.  I've got a wife and two children who expect to wake up every morning with food on the table and heat in the house.   I got a mortgage.  I got car payments.  I got Ma's medical bills. Oh yeah, and I got you.  Yeah, you.   Jack the shadow who's so cool and so hip and so fucking sure he's better than everyone else.  Don't you think I'd like to walk up to one of these assholes and blow smoke in his face?  Goddamn right I would.   But I can't.  Because I have to be responsible, little brother.  I have to make sure the numbers balance out in my favor at the end of each month so everyone can go on living their lives.  You don't win medals for it, but you can be damn sure you'd all take notice if I folded up shop.  So don't talk to me about dignity, little brother.  You're drawing on a weak hand. Jack stares at Frank through the rain, then turns and begins to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.  Terrific.  Walk away.  You're good at that, Jack.  Just don't forget to stop off for another bottle of courage on your way home. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what he'd do. Jack stops, his back to Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've found the perfect solution to all the pain in the world, haven't you, little brother?   Eight-fifty a bottle, available any time day or night at your friendly neighborhood liquor store.   You're weak, Jack.  Just like he was. Jack turns, tough and dangerous in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay off it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, let's stay on it.  I'm sick and tired of watching you make him up into some kinda god.   For Christ sake, Jack, he died doing a stupid bullshit jig.  He left a wife and two sons.  He wasn't a hero.  He was a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eerily cold)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  I wasn't there.  I don't have the luxury of being a witness to tragedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coiled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, fuck you.  And fuck him too. Fuck the both-of you. Jack suddenly bolts for,ward and grabs Frank by the lapels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what're you doing?  Hey! Jack flings Frank against the wall, pounding, pulling and slamming him in a fitful rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; scared)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack! ... Jack! ... Frank slides to the ground, afraid, trying to protect himself.  Jack hovers over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it feel to have your little brother beat the shit out of you?  Huh?  Huh! Jack comes down with a vicious fist at Frank's face.   Frank holds up his hands, trying to shield himself, and catches a blow on his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My hands!  My hands! Jack grabs one of Frank's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mocking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your hands.  Your hands couldn't take the blue ribbon on amateur night. Jack bends back Frank's fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's weak now, big brother? Jack pushes Frank's fingers until the knuckles crack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack!  JACK! Frank's voice echoes high above the sound of the rain.   Suddenly Jack stops.  Looking at Frank's hand, still clasped in his, he seems as shocked by his own behavior as Frank.  Letting go, he steps back awkwardly and looks at his brother, beaten, to the ground, his tuxedo ripped and dirty.  He stares at his own hands, the knuckles spli and bleeding.  He no longer looks dangerous.  He looks hollow, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm through with it.  I can't do it anymore. Frank, rubbing his fingers, glances up at Jack, but Jack just turns away, leaving Frank on the sidewalk, and disappears into the rain.  MUSIC begins.  A sad, plaintiv solo piano.  And we see:

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: Jack, crossing the street to his apartment, the rain over now. Frank, driving home, his face swollen and bruised in the dim glow of the streetlights. Jack, letting himself into his apartment and standing there.  Alone. Frank, easing the car into the driveway, turning off the engine. Jack, taking a bottle from the kitchen, moving numbly. Frank, much later, still sitting in the driveway as the sun begins to come up. Jack, sitting in the phone booth, the bottle in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning.  Jack is sitting on the windowsill, watching the RAIN DRUM the GLASS.  He glances at the phon across the room, takes another look at the rain, then goe to the phone.  He picks it up hesitantly, then dials.   It rings.  Again.  Again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Jack blinks.  It's Cindy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello ... Hellooooo ... (fainter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy.  Daddy!  Someone's on the phone and they won't talk. Jack sets the phone back down on the cradle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stands in a dark bar.  It is early morning and the light from the street gives the room a ghostly atmosphere A big, beefy MAN with a bar towel hooked in his belt is talking to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they wanna talk about their wife, you listen.   If they wanna talk about their job, you listen.   If they wanna talk about their parakeet, you listen.   That's it, six nights a week, nine to one or until I send you home.  Okay? Jack nods and points to the piano in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many you need? Jack walks over to the giano and strikes a note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's out of tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me, the way I fix a martini, it'll be in tune. The MUSIC RETURNS, sad and plaintive, and we see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, attempting to give piano lessons to a brother and sister tandem who would be better served by an obedience school.  While the little girl pounds incessantly on the piano, her brother runs circles around the room, destroying everything in sight. MUSIC CONTINUES and we see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Eddie, going for a walk, passing the diner where Jack and Frank's pictures are still displayed. MUSIC CONTINUES and we see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, in the bar, playing the music we've been hearing throughout the previous scenes.  It is after midnight and the tables are empty.  Only a few somber men remain at the bar.  They do not appear to be music lovers.   As Jack finishes, he takes a cloth and wipes the keys.   There is a glass on the piano with money in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought the Bakers didn't take tips. Jack glances up, but he knows the voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I give it all to charity. Susie nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saw the sign outside.  Got your own sign, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Got my own sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We outgrew each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, like I said, it didn't figure.  You two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't pick your brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how's the cat food business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific.  I'm doing vegetables next week. Jack nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vegetables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Carrots.  And peas.  None of the important ones. Susie tries a smile.  Takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen... you want to get a drink?  I got a new place.  Or we could go to a bar ... (looking around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe not a bar.  But I know a place uptown, if you want --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've given it up. Susie stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding?  Well ... I guess you can't do a reunion over tomato juice, can you? (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, if you're ever in the neighborhood ... I wrote it down. Susie takes a slip of paper from her purse and hands it to Jack.  They lock eyes for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell egghead I said hi.  If you see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I see him. Susie nods and walks toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. (as she stops)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got pretty eyes. Susie smiles.  As she leaves, Jack studies the slip of paper in his hand, then drops it in the tip glass.   He glances at the door, swinging slowly shut in Susie's wake, then reaches into his coat and takes out a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank sits alone in the darkness of the den.  The cardboard stand-up is there, along with several old photographs, including one showing two skinny kids in tuxes standing with a glamorous Peggy Lee.  After a momen Donna enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank?  It's late, honey. Frank stays staring at the photograph of Peggy Lee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lerner called after dinner.  Robbie can't make his lesson tomorrow. Donna waits for her husband to say something, then sees t photograph in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how good he is?  It's like breathing with him.  I've always envied it.  But tonight, looking at all this -- at his face -- I don't know.   Maybe it's worse.  For him. (gesturing to the piano)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's funny.  When I sit here and play ... nothing.   But when I was up there with him... It was like I had the gift, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is standing in the hallway of his house, leaning against the bathroom door.  It's locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Jeremy.  Open the door. Somewhere in the house, the PHONE RINGS.   Frank ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeremy.  You want me to call your father?   He's not going to be very happy when he hears he's spending fifteen dollars an hour for you to sit on the toilet. Donna, looking shaken, steps into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe this?  The kid won't come out.  I'm playing 'Camptown Races' for him and the next thing I know he's locked himself in the bathroom.   There's nothing sharp in there, is there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are our kids?   Has he got one of them in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank. Frank finally looks at his wife.  She's crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack rushes down a hospital corridor and heads for the nurses station.  As he moves to the counter, Donna appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna.  Where is she? Donna just shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We tried the apartment, but after that we didn't know where to call. Jack looks frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank'll be back in a moment.   He took Little Frank to the bathroom. Jack begins to back away slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack moves aimlessly down the street, slipping in and out of shadows.  Finally he stops inside a closed storefront, his back up against the window, and looks down at his hands.  They're shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stands in an apartment hallway, waiting.   After a moment, the door opens.  It's Susie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this is some surprise. (seeing his face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey ... You don't look so good, pal. Susie studies Jack as he glances around the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack? Jack looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to come in? He nods.  Susie steps back and Jack enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. He stares directly into her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is standing at the foot of the bed, looking down at Susie's naked back as she sleeps.  He studies her face as if looking for something, then takes his coat and begins to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to do that. Jack turns.  Susie is looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sneak out in the morning.  Before the guy could wake up and ruin it.  Never figured I'd be on the other end of it, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to wake you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling slightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.  For letting me in last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny how life repeats itself, huh?  Over and over.   Like a song. Jack looks at Susie for a long moment, then nods and turns for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Jack stops, his hand on the doorknob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I gonna see you again? Jack looks at her face, beautiful in the morning light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  You're gonna see me again. Susie smiles slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is standing across the street from his mother's house, just looking.  After a moment, he crosses the street.  As he moves up the drive, he takes notice of the tree growing in the front yard and crosses to it, kneeling by the trunk and studying the scars there -- cat's claws -- running vertically up the tree, the damage smoothed and widened by time.  He runs his fingers over the imperfection, then stands and walks toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the screen door, Jack can hear a CLICKING sound and see partially into the front door.  Half the room is cast in shadow, the other in blinding light. He opens the door and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, the movie PROJECTOR is RUNNING, the tail of a completed FLIP SLAPPING like a whip against the carriage. Jack TURNS OFF the PROJECTOR and the room falls entirely into shadow.  For a moment, the house is silent, full of ghosts, then, gradually, a NOISE is heard coming from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jack comes into the kitchen, he finds Frank searching through a cabinet.  He watches for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you looking for? Frank turns quickly, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't hear you come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh ... I was just hoping for something to drink.  But it seems the old lady was dry. Not even a bottle of cooking sherry. Jack nods.  Frank looks nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, we already boxed some things.  I figured you'd want to go through Dad's stuff.  It's in there.   If you want to get started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Frank nods.  Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is everything done?  The arrangements, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah.  It was all worked out before, you know.   She and Dad had taken care of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I set it for Wednesday.  The ceremony.  They're doing the stone today. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay?  Wednesday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not going to be a viewing. I figured with the kids and all ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Jack glances around the room.  Pictures on the walls.   Handmade curtains, lightly faded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's funny.  Before, whenever I came here, the house seemed small.  But today ... I can't keep up with it. I keep losing my wind. Frank smiles slightly and he and Jack lock eyes for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing;glancing away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I could use a drink. Jack hesitates, then pulls a bottle out of his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, great.  I'll get a couple glasses. Frank moves to a cabinet, but there's nothing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.  Donna must've packed them up this morning. Jack holds out the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (showing the seal is unbroken)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bought it on the way over.  Clean as a nun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not that.  I ... can't drink from the bottle.  I ... gag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, right.  I forgot. Frank looks embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (remembering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hey, I want to show you something.  Come on. Jack follows Frank back into the front room.  Frank stands before one of the tiny matching pianos and gestures Jack to the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit the C. Go ahead. Jack steps over to the other piano and taps, then Frank does the same.  Jack glances up in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm right, aren't I? They're in tune. Jack hits the note again and nods in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All these years.  She kept them in tune.   Can you imagine?   Now why would she do something like that? Frank looks down at the keys and his smile fades.   Suddenly he notices the collection of tiny souvenir shot glasses on top of the piano, each bearing the name of a different hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what do you know.  Looks like we can have that drink after all. (picking up a few glasses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your pleasure?  We got the downtown Ramada.   We got the Travelodge on Route 41.   And ... the Mallory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take the Mallory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good choice. Frank blows some dust off the glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like these got a few years on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This'll kill 'em. Jack pours and he and Frank settle on the tiny piano benches.  As Frank swallows, he winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. It suddenly grows silent, each sitting in his old familiar place, staring into his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're your hands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Fine.  It was nothing.  Couple sore knuckles.  Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, that night, I ... It just all came up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know.  Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, you can play.  You're okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can keep the beat. Jack smiles slightly, then both go back to their glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Larry Shelton.  Blackie.  Couple others.   Donna said even Lloyd called the other day.   Nothing like a little absence to make the heart grow fonder, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Jack and Frank lock eyes again.   Frank's glance drops to Jack's glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, when was the last time we played the Mallory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five years ago. (thinking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: November.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.  It was someone's birthday. Halloran?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daughter's.  Sweet sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, that's right.  How could I forget.  What a nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She asked for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told Halloran we didn't do vocals, but he said:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in unison)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What my Sissy-wants, my Sissy gets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She got it all right. Jack and Frank glance at one another, little boy mischief glowing in their faces.  Suddenly they swivel on the pianos and begin to play "You're Sixteen."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes on like a dream Peaches and cream Lips like strawberry wine She's sixteen, she's beautiful and she's mine. Ribbons and curls Ooh, what a girl Eyes that sparkle and shine You're sixteen, you're beautiful, and you're mine. As Jack and Frank finish, they're laughing.  After a moment, their voices die and the house is quiet again.   Full of ghosts.  Each stares at the tiny keyboard before him, awkward with the intimacy of the moment.  It is quiet for a very long time.  Finally, Frank looks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... One more time? Jack glances up and sees Frank has his empty glass held out.  He hesitates, then picks up the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more time.
